Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

sbcraver@gmail.com
Saturday, August 1, 2020 6:31 PM
City Council
City Clerk
Urgent Arts Funding Concern for Cambridge re: August 10th Meeting Agenda

Dear Cambridge City Council Members:

I am writing in deep concern over the Council’s recent decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits, specifically 
considering how this will impact Studio at 550, an essential resource for dance in the Cambridge ecosystem. 

I am a dancer, choreographer, and former staff member of The Dance Complex; I am based in Somerville, MA 
with strong ties to the arts in Cambridge. With the recent abrupt closure of Green Street Studios, the huge 
impact of the COVID-19 crisis on the arts, and a constant push for gentrification that further raises the costs of 
rent and existence in Central Square, Cambridge and its surrounding cities and towns need the presence of 
Studio@550 now more than ever. When not in pandemic times, I find myself in Central Square very often to 
take class, attend performances, and share ideas with members of the dance community. I know from 
firsthand experience working with teaching artists that Studio@550 is a crucial resource for keeping dance 
classes, rehearsals, and performances alive in Cambridge. My former job was to help artists find this much-
needed space on a daily basis, so I am deeply aware of the challenges these artists face. The need for space to 
practice this art form is urgent, and it cannot be ignored or pushed to later dates without dire financial 
consequences for those who need the help most. There simply is no more space – let alone affordable space.

The Council’s decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits deeply affects Studio@550’s ability to relocate in 
September and may result in its closure. Studio at 550 is just one example of the small arts organizations in 
Cambridge that house many other arts businesses, organizations, and entrepreneurs, and its closure would 
damage the viability of the entire dance landscape in Cambridge and beyond. I therefore implore that you put 
the City Manager's order which would amend the Mayor's Disaster Relief Fund to include arts organizations on 
the special meeting agenda scheduled for August 10th.

The City Council’s attention and action on this matter are requested immediately.

Sincerely,

Sarah Craver
Former staff member at The Dance Complex
Member of the greater Boston arts community as a dancer, choreographer, student, and patron

City Council; City Clerk
Arts Organization Support

My name is Ellice Patterson. I am a dancer/choreographer/artistic director in the greater Boston/Cambridge area. I am 
writing in support of other artistic organizations to request you put the City Manager's order which would amend the 
Mayor's Disaster Relief Fund to include arts organizations on the special meeting agenda scheduled for Aug 10. This 
support is critical to keep salaries and lights on throughout this difficult time and by effect giving our community a much 
needed artistic morale boost to keep us all going strong.

Perez, Lori

From:

chavi bansal <chav.bansal@live.com>
Wednesday, August 5, 2020 10:21 PM
City Council
City Clerk
Studio 550 

Dear Cambridge City Council Members,

I am writing in deep concern over the Council’s recent decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits, 
specifically considering how this will impact Studio at 550, an essential resource for dance in the 
Cambridge ecosystem. 

I am a professional choreographer based in Cambridge. I teach out the 2 existing studios in Cambridge, 
Studio 550 and the Dance Complex. Besides that, I also run a modern dance company providing 
employment to fellow dancers, teaching classes to local residents, performing in local festivals in the city.
The Cambridge dance community was already hit hard with the recent closure of Green Street Studios, 
but the impacts of the pandemic have continued to threaten our vibrant arts landscape. The Council’s 
decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits deeply affects Studio at 550’s ability to relocate in September 
and may result in its closure. Studio at 550 is just one example of the small arts organizations in 
Cambridge that house many other arts businesses, organizations, and entrepreneurs, and its closure 
would damage the viability of the entire dance landscape in Cambridge and beyond. I therefore implore 
that you put the City Manager's order which would amend the Mayor's Disaster Relief Fund to include 
arts organizations on the special meeting agenda scheduled for August 10th.

The city council’s attention and action on this matter are requested immediately.

Sincerely,
Chavi Bansal
Vimoksha dance company  
https://www.chavibansal.org/
https://www.chavibansalyoga.com/

City Council
City Clerk
Help Studio 550

Dear Cambridge City Council Members,

I am writing in deep concern over the Council’s recent decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits, specifically 
considering how this will impact Studio at 550, an essential resource for dance in the Cambridge ecosystem.

I am a professional improvisational dance/theatre artist based in Lexington with strong ties to the arts in 
Cambridge. I rehearsed, performed, and viewed dance regularly in Central Square. I have fostered important 
mentorships and peer relationships through my creative work in Cambridge. Access to Cambridge dance 
spaces is crucial to the further development of my and others’ choreographic careers.

The Cambridge dance community was already hit hard with the recent closure of Green Street Studios, but the 
impacts of the pandemic have continued to threaten our vibrant arts landscape. The Council’s decision to 
delay funding to arts nonprofits deeply affects Studio at 550’s ability to relocate in September and may result 
in its closure. Studio at 550 is just one example of the small arts organizations in Cambridge that house many 
other arts businesses, organizations, and entrepreneurs, and its closure would damage the viability of the 
entire dance landscape in Cambridge and beyond. I therefore implore that you put the City Manager's order 
which would amend the Mayor's Disaster Relief Fund to include arts organizations on the special meeting 
agenda scheduled for August 10th.

The city council’s attention and action on this matter are requested immediately.

Sincerely,

Jessica Roseman

Licensed Massage Therapist

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Karen Krolak <kskrolak@gmail.com>
Monday, August 10, 2020 1:59 PM
City Council; City Clerk
Studio at 550 funding

Dear Cambridge City Council Members,

I am writing in deep concern over the Council’s recent decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits, specifically 
considering how this will impact Studio at 550, an essential resource for dance in the Cambridge ecosystem.  

I am a professional interdisciplinary dance artist based in Malden, MA who has been a part of the arts 
community in Cambridge for over 20 years. In addition to my role as the co-Artistic Director of Monkeyhouse, 
an award-winning nonprofit that connects communities with choreography, I am also an artist advisor to both 
the Boston Dance Alliance and the Dance Complex. Having multiple venues where people can rehearse, 
perform, and train within a short distance of one another is vital to the dance ecosystem here. Hundreds of 
people depend upon these spaces. Frankly speaking, we need more dance venues not less.

The Cambridge dance community was already hit hard with the recent closure of Green Street Studios, but the 
impacts of the pandemic have continued to threaten our vibrant arts landscape. The Council’s decision to 
delay funding to arts nonprofits deeply affects Studio at 550’s ability to relocate in September and may result 
in its closure. Studio at 550 is just one example of the small arts organizations in Cambridge that house many 
other arts businesses, organizations, and entrepreneurs, and its closure would damage the viability of the 
entire dance landscape in Cambridge and beyond. I therefore implore that you put the City Manager's order 
which would amend the Mayor's Disaster Relief Fund to include arts organizations on the next special meeting 
agenda.

The city council’s attention and action on this matter are requested immediately.

Sincerely,

Karen Krolak

--
Co-Founder/Artistic Director
Monkeyhouse - Connecting Communities through Choreography
Upcoming events:
Remember Me at Council on Aging in Medford, MA
Empower One Another at OnStage in Malden, MA

DictionaryofNegativeSpace Creator
Upcoming events:
Circle at CICA Museum in Gimpo, Korea
A Case for Never Going Anywhere Again at Institute for Conceptual Studies online
Public Art Learning Fund grant from the New England Foundation for the Arts in Boston, MA

Packet Pg. 360

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Dear City Council Members,

Diane C Norris <diane@charyknorris.net>
Monday, August 3, 2020 4:19 PM
City Council
City Clerk
Emergency Relief and Grant Criteria for Arts Organizations

I am writing this letter to encourage adding Arts Organizations as a beneficiary of the Mayor's Disaster Relief Funding to the special meeting in 
August, as a time sensitive issue. Arts organizations that need emergency help with utility bills, rent, and/or face evictions cannot wait until 
September. I appreciate Councilor Simmons’ quick response to Kristie to explain her charter rights and her concerns to our Reopening 
Committee, it is very helpful to get the feedback. I do understand that clarification is needed to strengthen the policy order, but also hope it can 
be resolved in timely manner.

In response to concerns about establishing criteria, I’d like to clarify that Cambridge Arts can readily offer criteria guidelines input. Cambridge 
Arts is in the process of developing new grant guidelines for both the Art for Racial Justice and Annual Grant Programs that will be ready for the 
next grant cycle very soon. Working in response to Covid-19, BLM, and MCC guidelines, I have no doubt that they will be very robust with 
appropriate outreach, checks, and balances. I encourage the City Council to become familiar with them and would be pleased to answer any 
questions or concerns you may have. Moving forward, I am very thankful to Vice Mayor Alanna Mallon and the City of Cambridge for the well 
appreciated increase in the Arts Grant Programs budget. I am very thankful that it will now be able to serve more artists in need, a broader 
community, and more neighborhoods.  Sadly, however, this funding does not solve the emergency funding for survival that several arts 
organizations now face.

I’d like to highlight some examples of recipients from the 2019-20 grant cycle to clarify how many projects have a focus on social healing, 
engagement, and community building, especially at this difficult time. The variety of art mediums represented is also helpful to reach different 
audiences. I am pleased that Cambridge Arts puts a strong focus on helping artists to establish creative partnerships to strengthen their access 
and impact on broader communities in Cambridge.

Here are a few examples, (for full list, see link at end):

DANCE
Studio at 550: Creative Residency 2020 - In less than 4 years Studio at 550 has grown to serve over 650+ artists working in many artistic 
disciplines.
Dance in the Schools: Dance Teaching Artists into the 12 Cambridge Public School classrooms
Japanese Cultural Show:
Cultivate: original works by female and non-binary disabled choreographers and a team of musicians/composers with hope to further promote 
intersectional disability rights through art.

MUSIC
Shelter Music Boston: Transformative Concerts at CASPAR Emergency Shelter
Cambridge Community Center: The Hip Hop Transformation
Longy School of Music: Healing Art Initiative - hybrid of music and medicine
Walter Chapin: Epiphanies
New Gallery Concert Series: From There to Here - work as literal as a train whizzing by to the musical retelling of a Holocaust survivor’s 
personal journey.
Skooby Lapofsky: Hidden Life Radio - aims to increase the general awareness of trees in Cambridge and the city’s disappearing canopy.
Aaron King: Bridgeside Cypher - rappers hosted at Graffiti Alley in Central Square
Erik Lindgren: Oral Moses in Concert - bass baritone from Atlanta, African American Spiritual.
Alex Lemski: The Creative Music Series - adventurous jazz; bringing out-of-town musicians with national reputations paying attention to social 
and cultural realities; booking musicians as leaders who are women and musicians of color.

THEATER
Central Square Theater: The Voting Project - Act Up and Vote!
Faye Dupras: Cozy Corner: Dragon Next Door
Jade Sylcan: Beloved King - Beloved King is a full-length musical based on a queer reading of the book of Samuel in the Bible.
Grace Valaskovic: Annabel Lee - Noah learns to cope with the death of his once-beloved Annabel Lee and heal the damage he has inflicted on 
himself and those around him.
Queen Mab: The Tempest – Three African-American actors – one of whom is deaf – will dive deep into the play's reflections on colonial power, 
and how it controls not just the way we express ourselves, but our very sense of self. Resonances of the immigrant experience and the dignity 
of marginalized peoples abound. Shakespeare’s transcendent language takes center stage, both as spoken English and translated into 
American Sign Language.

LITERATURE

4.23.a

1

Packet Pg. 361

4.23.a

Patricia Russo: Partners in Rhyme - Ten older adults from Cambridge and 20 teens from the Gately Youth Center, an intergenerational poetry 
program, at the Cambridge Senior Center.
Kenny Likis: Voices that Inspire - “Voices That Inspire” will bring two speakers / performers to Cambridge: Fatimah Asghar and Dr. Billie Jean 
Young. Dr. Young will perform her play at CRLS and in a public forum. The plan is for the performance in a public forum to be followed by a 
panel discussion featuring women elected to public office.

MULTIDISCIPLINARY
Zoe Dance Company: Metamorfosi
Family Opera Inc.: The Cutlass Crew
Cambridge Wildlife Puppetry Project: Animal Homes - multidisciplinary arts campaign, with STEAM elements, that will enable at least 300 
individuals—primarily Cambridge families with children under 12
Poetry is Busy, Visible Caribe Series - invited poets, dancers, writers, filmmakers, performers, musicians, and visual artists, originally located in 
Puerto Rico
Innovators for Purpose: Looking Glass Live! - In iFp Studios, teens create installations that enable their voices to be heard in the city's most 
innovative places.

VISUAL ARTS, FILM, & VIDEO
Thomas J. Briggs: Homeless Artists Workshop
Boston Comic Arts Foundation: Massachusetts Independent Comics Expo 2020 - Free weekend event for all ages hosted by Lesley University 
College of Art and Design.
Robert Megerdichian: Love in Metal - machinist, lifelong Cambridge resident.
Jessica Hankey: Orbis Editions - small press artists’ publications with public events that reinforce the role of print media.
Brain Arts Organization, Inc.: Black Market Flea
CCTV: Our Central Square

The full link of grant recipients with descriptions is here:
https://www.cambridgema.gov/arts/Programs/Grants/20192020grantrecipients

On the left you can also see the extensive list of grant recipients for previous years and the panelists listed for each year by discipline. Over 
several years, I have found that Cambridge Arts is very intentional about the professionals they reach out to. The list of reviewers changes 
each year to ensure a fair process. They now pay panelists an honorarium to make sure that reviewers are compensated for their time and 
work in the deliberations and panel meetings. As a board member of Cambridge Arts, I also welcome feedback and suggestions for panelists 
to ensure multiple voices and perspectives are represented.

Best Regards, Diane

Diane Norris
Chair, Cambridge Arts Advisory Board
www.charyknorris.net
www.millerstreetstudios.net
www.norrisnorris.com
617-699-7457

From:

Josie Thaddeus-Johns <jthaddeusjohns@gmail.com>
Monday, August 3, 2020 3:26 PM
City Council; Clerk
Traffic enforcement proposal

Hi, as a resident of Cambridge, I fully support the proposal to remove traffic enforcement from the purview of the 
Cambridge Police Department. I strongly believe that city employees are fully capable of enforcing traffic violations and 
doing so without the racist motivations that are endemic in the police department. This way, I hope that one day the 
violence and oppression associated with "driving while black" will not be a part of local Cambridge life.

Thanks
Josie

--
Josie Thaddeus-Johns
http://josietj.com
+18578560695
Skype: josie.thaddeus-johns

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:
Attachments:

##

Becca Schofield <beccascho@gmail.com>
Tuesday, August 4, 2020 9:24 AM
Planning Board Comment
Clerk
ABC support for AHO and JAS Rindge Commons
Rindge Commons - ABC letter of support.docx

Dear Members of the Planning Board,

Apologies for the delay here, email got caught in my outbox yesterday. Attaching a support letter for Just A Start's 
Rindge Commons project, and personal support for the AHO proposal below.

Many thanks, and hoping these notes can still be included in the record for this evening's meeting.

I’m writing as a strong supporter of the 100% Affordable Housing Overlay. I am very grateful this policy proposed has 
come back to the Planning Board in 2020 - in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, with a spotlight on deep equities 
nationwide, we need effective zoning reform and affordable housing now more than ever. I believe the AHO is an 
essential tool for building more affordable housing in Cambridge and preventing the displacement of low- and 
moderate-income families from our City.

For local affordable housing nonprofits to compete with market rate developers, the Overlay’s provision to allow for 
more density as-of-right is key to the success of this policy. I urge this committee not to water-down the current 
proposal - to limit density or include additional dimensional or permitting requirements would add costs and likely make 
many affordable housing developments infeasible, even if the AHO does move forward. If this zoning proposal is truly 
going to help affordable housing developers build, the current density and as-of-right provisions described cannot be 
weakened. The citywide, comprehensive zoning proposal before you is the culmination of years of due diligence and 
expertise; please support the AHO as written.

In my conversations with friends and neighbors against the Overlay, it's become clear that discomfort with an as-of-right 
provision is not based on affordable housing but market rate projects where developers 1) did not have an inclusive 
community process and 2) weren't responsive to local concerns. Affordable housing developments are held to local and 
state-level requirements on community meetings, impact assessments, and other due diligence - an as-of-right provision 
through a successful AHO would not limit process.

Affordable housing developers work closely with City staff to acquire and finance projects and meet with the Community 
Development Dept. at various stages of building design. Public lenders weigh in on design details, sustainability 
measures, and other components of the proposed project before providing funding. Throughout Cambridge, affordable 
housing is high-quality and responsive to both City and community feedback. I am confident this will not change with an 
as-of-right provision.

Cambridge's affordable housing stock is some of the most sustainable, energy efficient, and resilient around. In 
my experience, when mission-driven developers have an opportunity to build new housing we recognize the positive 
impact of good design and quality materials on the well-being of residents and the durability of their homes. Healthier 
buildings and lower carbon footprints are integral to the mission of local nonprofit developers, and the Overlay 
will support this responsible development approach.

1

Packet Pg. 364

4.25.a

In our current market, affordable housing nonprofits are unable to put bids on properties that come up for sale because 
of the substantial acquisition costs. Market developers are more likely to pay high asking prices because they can make 
their investment back with higher rents and/or condo sales, but this doesn't pencil out for affordable housing. We must 
act now, through passing the Overlay and simplifying the development process (i.e. reducing up-front costs, not limiting 
design process or accountability!) for affordable housing projects. This is just one key step in protecting affordable 
housing for the long-term and ensuring that more people - from many income levels, backgrounds, education, 
employment, etc. - can afford to stay in Cambridge.  

In the midst of an incredibly challenging public health crisis and a political climate full of fear and inequity, our effort to 
build more housing and provide stability for lower-income families in Cambridge is a small but essential action our 
community must take. Please don't wait any long to pass the AHO.

Thank you for your consideration, and please reach out if you'd like to discuss further.

Becca Schofield
Co-chair, A Better Cambridge (ABC) and Project Manager, Homeowner's Rehab Inc. (HRI)

Packet Pg. 365

Rindge Commons – Proposed Just-A-Start Development – Letter of Support 
August 3, 2020 
 
To Members of the Planning Board, 
 
A Better Cambridge (ABC) has been a long-time housing advocate in the Cambridge. We’re 
proud to reach out in support of Just-A-Start’s Rindge Commons project, a proposed infill 
development that will provide 101 new affordable apartments at a transit-oriented site. Rindge 
Commons will also include a job training center, early childhood education space, and other on-
site services that support the existing community at 402 Rindge and future Rindge Commons 
residents. 
 
JAS’s experience developing affordable housing in Cambridge and the community process 
they’ve begun – with resident meetings, public meetings, and open houses allowing for 
neighborhood feedback and an opportunity to learn more about Rindge Commons – 
demonstrates their connection to the neighborhood and thoughtful planning for this new 
construction project. We believe Rindge Commons will maximize the potential of this site, 
which is currently an under-utilized parking lot. 
 
The Rindge Commons design shows a site plan with active walking paths, resilient landscaping, 
and several spaces for families to gather and connect. Instead of an asphalt lot, Cambridge will 
gain 101 new apartments for families at 80% AMI or below, meeting an urgent need for more 
affordable housing options. Rindge Commons, along with existing housing at this site (402 
Rindge and Fresh Pond Apartments) is a short walk from Alewife T station and the Minuteman 
bike trail; all residents will have access to healthier, more sustainable travel options. 
 
Our board has reviewed the details of JAS’s proposed Rindge Commons development, and 
we’re encouraged by their community-oriented design and focus on both providing supportive 
services for residents and minimizing the environmental impact of new construction. We hope 
the Planning Board will support this much-needed affordable development. 
 
Sincerely, 
A Better Cambridge (ABC) Board and Steering Committee

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Jane Hirschi <jhirschi@citysprouts.org>
Wednesday, August 5, 2020 8:18 AM
City Council; Clerk; Paden, Liza
Support for 585 Third Street

To the Planning Board and City Council,

On behalf of Cambridge nonprofit CitySprouts, I would like to register my support for BioMed Realty and their 
designs for 585 Third Street. BioMed is a valued sponsor of our work, and has repeatedly shown its 
commitment to the community by supporting us and through the involvement of its Executive Vice President, 
Bill Kane, who sits on our Board of Directors. Through these relationships, we have come to appreciate the 
active role that BioMed plays in fostering community growth and believe them to be exactly the kind of 
developers that the City of Cambridge should encourage.

Even without this personal experience with BioMed, however, their proposal would earn our support on its 
merits alone. CitySprouts gives Cambridge children opportunities for hands-on learning through urban 
gardens, and 585 Third Street would add much-needed green space to the steel-and-glass streetscape of 
Kendall Square. We look forward to collaborating with BioMed Realty in finding ways for young people to take 
advantage of the new landscaping opportunities their community space would bring. We are also excited about 
the landscaping planned for the setback intervals at various elevations in the building’s design; verticality is an 
important aspect of urban gardening, where space is always at a premium. It also sends a good message to 
young people- that plant life should be cultivated everywhere, especially in places you’d least expect it.

I encourage you to support this proposal and would welcome the opportunity to discuss this endorsement in 
further detail should you desire.

Thank you for your time.

Jane Hirschi, Executive Director
www.citysprouts.org

The CitySprouts mission is to cultivate wonder for all children with hands-on learning through urban gardening.

City Manager
City Council; Bard, Branville G.; Clerk
Re: Cambridge Police refusing to process License to Carry applications

Good Morning City Manager DePasquale,

I am writing a third reminder to ask about my concern about the Cambridge Police. I wrote on 8/25 and 9/1, and called 
your office twice, yet have not received a response or an acknowledgement. Can you please address this 
constitutional violation by the Cambridge Police Department and urge them to begin processing LTC applications 
immediately? 

On Tue, Sep 1, 2020 at 7:27 AM Luis Mejias <lmejias@gmail.com> wrote:
Good morning - I am following up since I have not received acknowledgement of receipt or a response.

Begin forwarded message:

From: Luis Mejias <lmejias@gmail.com>
Date: August 25, 2020 at 17:18:52 EDT
To: citymanager@cambridgema.gov, council@cambridgema.gov, bbard@cambridgepolice.org
Subject: Cambridge Police refusing to process License to Carry applications

Good afternoon,

I am writing to express concern that the Cambridge Police Department is in violation of state law and 
the US Constitution by refusing to process License to Carry applications, citing the COVID-19 emergency 
as justification to essentially deny citizens' rights. 

I submitted my application on June 30th and was told that the Cambridge Police has stopped 
processing applications, effectively denying our constitutional rights. When I pressed further, I was 
also told to apply with the Massachusetts State Police, who then told me they do not process LTC 
applications.

I contacted the Attorney General's Office, who led me to the State Firearms Licensing Board, and they 
instructed me to contact your office as you have control of the police department. CPB tells me that 
they aren't processing applications due to safety/COVID, however, two people at the Firearms Records

Director Joseph Barr

The Honorable City Council

      RE: Rethinking our Streets initiative 
   
Dear Director Barr, Honorable City Council, and City Manager DePasquale: 
 
At the July 22, 2020, East Cambridge Planning Team (ECPT) meeting, the Rethinking our Streets initiative 
(RoSi) team presented their widely promoted neighborhood survey and a proposal for shared streets in 
East Cambridge. After deliberating, the ECPT resolved to support the work of the RoSi in light of the 
existing COVID-19 pandemic. We encourage City officials to fully engage with RoSi to evaluate, plan, and 
implement the proposals as soon as possible. 
 
Very truly yours, 
 
 
 
Charles T. Hinds 
President, ECPT

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Sasha Peterson <sasha.petey@gmail.com>
Monday, August 17, 2020 3:10 PM
City Council
City Clerk
Regarding Studio 550

Dear Cambridge City Council Members,

I am writing in deep concern over the Council’s recent decision to delay funding to arts nonprofits, specifically 
considering how this will impact Studio at 550, an essential resource for dance in the Cambridge ecosystem.  

I am a professional contemporary dance artist based in Somerville with strong ties to the arts in Cambridge. 
Cambridge has been the hub of dance for me my entire life. I have engaged in the arts in the city since I was in 
my early teens and continue to now. I have taken classes, performed, and taught at Green Street Studios, Jose 
Mateo Ballet Theatre, The Dance Complex, and Studio 550. Without these institutions in Cambridge, my dance 
training and career would be no more. I cannot begin to fully express how crucial the arts are in this city. 
They’ve shaped who I am, and so many other folks in the Boston area. Studio 550 in particular has enabled me 
to continue my dance career and passion. Whether that has been taking classes with Lion’s Jaw Festival in 
2016, or performing in the space multiple times, or rehearsing there for a myriad of projects, Callie has offered 
her space to me and my colleagues and truly fostered the arts community in Cambridge.

The Cambridge dance community was already hit hard with the recent closure of Green Street Studios, but the 
impacts of the pandemic have continued to threaten our vibrant arts landscape. The Council’s decision to 
delay funding to arts nonprofits deeply affects Studio at 550’s ability to relocate in September and may result 
in its closure. Studio at 550 is just one example of the small arts organizations in Cambridge that house many 
other arts businesses, organizations, and entrepreneurs, and its closure would damage the viability of the 
entire dance landscape in Cambridge and beyond. I therefore implore that you put the City Manager's order 
which would amend the Mayor's Disaster Relief Fund to include arts organizations on the special meeting 
agenda scheduled for August 10th.

The city council’s attention and action on this matter are requested immediately.

Sincerely,
Sasha Peterson

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Marilyn Wellons <marilyn.wellons@yahoo.com>
Friday, August 21, 2020 6:38 PM
City Council; Clerk
Affordable Housing in Cambridge

Dear City Council, Ordinance Committee:

The Cambridge Residents Alliance lists worthwhile ways to provide more affordable housing. Going over the 
CRA's summary, I'm struck how compatible existing Res C-2B zoning requirements are with CRA's 
suggestions. The current Zoning Ordinance's Res C-2B's terms provide, I believe, a good way to achieve those 
goals. 

For what I hope is your convenience, I've pasted Res C-2B provisions below my signature rather than as an 
attachment, and with my emphasis.  

Main point: one simple way to increase construction of affordable housing citywide is for the City Council to 
reconfirm Res C-2B provisions, remove any Special Permit exceptions, and rezone all Bus A zones to Res C-
2B.

Even now, Res C-2B is Bus A zones' default for residential construction. If the need is to provide more 
affordable housing, to protect existing, local businesses, and to protect and increase green space, this change 
would do that for all new construction in those zones.

Again, simply changing Bus A zones to Res C-2B would help get new affordable housing, whether subject to 
Inclusionary Zoning or as dedicated 100% affordable. Notably, it would grandfather in existing business uses, 
and would preserve existing trees while requiring new green space for everyone's benefit.

 

Res C-2B.
New construction in Res C-2B districts may only be 4-story multifamily housing, It is thus subject to 
Inclusionary Zoning. New business uses are prohibited in Res C-2B zones, but existing businesses are 
grandfathered and small local businesses protected.

Res C-2B's mandated setback requirements are more than compatible with the Tree Ordinance. While they 
mandate trees and shrubs, they also prohibit construction both above and below ground in those setbacks. This 
is serious protection for existing trees.

Res C-2B zoning is the default for housing construction in all Bus A zones citywide. For example, Bus A zones 
include much of Cambridge Street, Fresh Pond Parkway, and the parking lot on Church St.. Changing all Bus 
A to Res C-2B would signal the city is serious, and thus greatly improve housing development throughout the 
city, and do it simply.

Again, rezoning Bus A to its Res C-2B housing default would not eliminate business uses. It would grandfather 
in existing ones and thus protect small local businesses.

An example of Res C-2B mass and landscaping is the former Inn at Harvard, 1201 Mass Ave.. Res C-2B 
setback language also applies to Bus B-1 and Bus B-2 zones on Mass Ave. An example of the 20' mandated 
green setbacks common to all three zones is the green setback behind 1030 Mass Ave.

1

Please note that the original Res C-2B requirements that setbacks be above and below ground have has been 
changed. The Planning Board may now grant Special Permits for basement, i.e., underground, apartments in 
those setbacks. Such construction, if allowed, would have destroyed the mature trees in 1030's setback and 
would do so elsewhere.

My thanks to CRA for careful work, and to the Council for keeping on in the pandemic.

Marilyn Wellons
651 Green Street

***************

Cambridge Zoning Ordinance Table 5-1's Res C-2B footnotes (a), (c), (k) provide the model for any 
rezoning for affordable housing.

Table 5-1.

  Table of Dimensional Requirements - Residential Districts

Footnotes:

(a) Measured from the centerline of the street, but in no case may a building be nearer the street than ten 
(10) feet. 

(c) In no case may a building be nearer the rear lot line than twenty (20) feet in Residence C-2, C-2B, C-
2A, C-3, C-3A, C-3B districts. In Residence C and C-1 districts, no building may be nearer the rear lot line 
than twenty (20) feet plus one additional foot of rear yard for each four feet that the depth of the lot exceeds 100 
feet, up to a maximum of thirty (30) feet. In Residence A-1, A-2, and B districts, no building may be nearer the 
rear lot line than twenty-five (25) feet plus one additional foot of rear yard for each four feet that the depth of 
the lot exceeds one hundred (100) feet, up to a maximum of thirty-five (35) feet. For purposes of this Footnote 
C, the lot depth shall be that distance measured along a line perpendicular to the front lot line and extending to 
that point on the rear lot line most distant from the front lot line.

(k) Yard Requirements in the Residence C-2B District 

1) Setbacks - In the Residence C-2B District, buildings shall comply with these yard requirements by 
being set back above and below ground. 

2) Green Area - general 

Two of the yards on a lot shall consist exclusively of green area as defined in section 2.000. Contrary to 
the provisions of said definition, hard surfaced walks and terraces shall not exceed twenty-five (25) 
percent of the area of each yard.   At a minimum, green area setback shall consist of permanently 
maintained densely planted trees and shrubs that may be expected to form within three (3) years after 
the time of planting a continuous unbroken, year round visual screen. Every effort shall be made to 
retain the best existing trees in said setbacks to meet the requirements this section in whole or in 
part. Plans for landscaping and maintenance shall be approved by the Committee on Public Planting as 

2

4.30.a

appointed by the City Manager.   No Certificate of Occupancy may be granted until landscaping under 
the terms of this section is completed. 

(3) Lots with more than four yards.   If the shape of a lot creates a situation where there are more than four 
yards, this green area requirement shall apply to half of the yards, rounded up in the instance of an odd number 
of yards. 

(4) Lots in two or more zoning districts. Where a zoning district boundary line or lines split a lot, a lot 
partially in the Residence C-2B district shall comply with provisions elsewhere in this zoning ordinance with 
regard to lots in two or more zoning districts, except that the setback and green area requirements of this 
footnote shall apply to all parts of the lot regardless of zoning district. 

(5) Lots abutting more restrictively zoned districts. When any lot abuts a more restrictively zoned 
district or districts, all yards abutting the more restrictively zoned district)s) shall be designated as yards 
required to comply with the green area requirements of this footnote. This provision shall apply to that 
quantity of abutting yards numbering up to and including the maximum number of green area yards required by 
this footnote. The total number of green area yards required on a lot shall not be changed by the 
provisions of this subsection (5). 

(6) Pedestrian and vehicular access.  

(a) When a yard used to satisfy the Green Area Open Space requirement of this footnote is 
a front yard, the Green Area Open Space may be interrupted by not more than one path 
for pedestrian access to the building. Said pedestrian path shall be constructed perpendicular 
to the lot line and shall not be more than eight (8) feet wide. The green area yard may also be 
interrupted by not more than one driveway constructed perpendicular to the lot line and 
which is not more than twelve (12) feet wide. 

(b) The sum of the width of the said pedestrian path and driveway may not exceed the 
setback provided by the smallest of the yards provided on the lot. 

(c) The areas allowed to be used for access under this subsection (6) shall be counted as 
part of the twenty-five (25) percent of the total required green area which is allowed to be 
use for hard surfaced walks and terraces for the front yard in which the access areas are 
constructed. 

(7) Townhouse Development When a lot is used for townhouse development, the provisions of this 
footnote shall apply to the lot before subdivision into townhouse lots. Subdivision into townhouse lots 
shall be done in such a manner as to not affect the application of this footnote to the entire unsubdivided 
lot. In particular, the pedestrian path and driveways allowed.  

********
n.b., Bus B1 and Bus B2 zones have footnote (e) for side and rear yard setbacks:

minimum of twenty (20) feet from the zoning district boundary line, notwithstanding anything to the 
contrary provided in Article 6.000 of this Ordinance. Said setback shall consist exclusively of landscaped 
green area as defined in Article 2.000. Where the zoning district boundary line splits a lot the minimum

Kelly Dolan <kelly.dolan.kd@gmail.com>
Tuesday, August 18, 2020 3:04 PM
ksalim@cpsd.us
doshea@ibgretire.com; City Council; City Manager; Clerk; Alfred Fantini
CRLS Remote Plan

The presentation of the CRLS remote learning plan was a complete disappointment Tuesday night. Clearly the CRLS 
Leadership Team cannot effectively create a remote learning plan. This was now the third or fourth iteration presented 
to the public, with little or no pedagogy included, while the vague discussions of taking this opportunity to  'reinvent" 
our educational system are completely terrifying.

There does not seem to be any focus or expectation for the amount or type of content able to be delivered, no clear 
plan how small group learning and discussions will occur, no plan for grading  and very very few details outside of the 
basic core subjects. Teachers will certainly not be working their contractual 6:25 minutes per day.

The fact that Principal Smith did not even know that the full day schedule starts on 9/28 and not 10/28 as stated in 
his presentation is yet one more red flag that this team needs help, and quickly.

We were also extremely disappointed to hear the CEA's letter to the District after all the work CPSD put into the hybrid 
plan for our most vulnerable students. Offering neither an effective remote plan nor any in-class instruction is 
completely unacceptable for a team of educators that have maintained their positions with a generous pay raise for the 
upcoming year. The children of this city should not continue to bear the brunt of our faltering systems.

We are extremely concerned about what will happen to our district as we remember the years when families fled CPSD 
and the high school nearly lost its accreditation because of the uncertainty and chaos inflicted upon the community by 
that administration.

Please stand strong for our children and do what you know is best for them.

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Hello Dr Salim-

Kelly Dolan
Greg Berndt
Upland Road

Carlone, Dennis
City Council; Clerk; Zondervan, Quinton; Sobrinho-Wheeler, Jivan; Siddiqui, Sumbul;

Written Public Comment for the Ordinance Committee (8/19/20) Re: Revised AHO, Tree 
Protection, Environmental Justice, and Equity
9FE017FC-FF13-472A-9F06-5D81459F2EB7.jpeg; 3010C7DD-F587-4C11-
A716-57F6B60CB06D.jpeg; 9EB91BBF-2FF9-4B94-BF8B-64AC00E4471F.jpeg

[Dear Mr. Wilson: I have searched city web pages in vain for instructions
on how to have this email included for the record for today's Ordinance
Committee Hearing. (I believe this is a severe deficiency in the information
provided to the public at the multitude of city web pages.) Would you please
include this in the record for today's hearing, and also add it as a "communication"
to the Council for their next meeting in September? I would appreciate it if
you would confirm that you've been able to do this. Thanks. James Williamson]

August 19, 2020

Re: Revised AHO

Dear Members of the Ordinance Committee and Co-Chairs:

It's my understanding that an amendment to last year’s AHO which
would have guaranteed lower income residents in Cambridge the
same protection for mature shade trees as all other residents
of Cambridge has been removed from this year’s revised version.
As far as I know, there has been no empirical study or evidence
presented which shows that saving mature shade trees necessarily
increases the costs of affordable housing. If so, is there any evidence
that such an increase is sufficient to warrant removing this protection
for lower income residents from the revised AHO?
To remove this city-wide protection from the AHO smacks of exactly
the opposite of the purported logic of the AHO itself, does it not? The
AHO would purportedly treat all of Cambridge "the same" for purposes
of "100 per cent affordable housing." Yet, when it comes to something
as essential and vitally important as what the experts call "tree canopy"
(and what the rest of us simply call "trees") it obviously does not.
Proponents of this feature of the revised AHO have been recently touting
their apparent rediscovery of "redlining" decades ago in Cambridge. Are
they not now advocating a latter-day imposition of another heinous form of
discrimination in housing when they assert that "poor people don't need (or

1

Packet Pg. 378

even care about) trees," and therefore don't deserve this equal protection??
(Perhaps it's time for these tree-haters to get re-acquainted with the 14th
Amendment to the US Constitution.)
The CHA plan to demolish all of the remaining brick buildings on what's
popularly known as the "Federal Side" of Jefferson Park (where, incidentally,
I live.) To do so, they will presumably destroy all of the existing mature
shade trees on the site, in order for architects to have a "tabula rasa" with
which to play. I would submit that this would be extremely detrimental to the
health and well-being of current and future residents of Jefferson Park but
would presumably be allowed "as of right," without public review, were the
AHO in its present form allowed to pass. I am enclosing some photographs
of the lovely tree canopy as it currently exists at Jefferson Park. (There would
be even more here had not two large trees in front of the building at 1000 Jackson
Place been killed as a result of what I believe was an avoidable maintenance
catastrophe only relatively recently.)
If you decide to pass this zoning change I urge you to seriously consider, at the very
least, a provision which would require a "developer" under the ordinance to demonstrate
the necessity for removing mature trees, including evidence of the cost of saving those
trees compared with abbreviated but reasonable evidence of the cost of a "reasonable
and prudent alternative" which would preserve those trees.
Thank you for working to truly respect the rights of all residents of Cambridge equally. 

Sincerely,  James Williamson
1000 Jackson Place
Jefferson Park
Cambridge, MA

Wednesday, August 19, 2020 3:48 AM
City Council; Clerk; Siddiqui, Sumbul
Sobrinho-Wheeler, Jivan; Nolan, Patricia; Zondervan, Quinton; Carlone, Dennis; Woolley, 
Shane; editor@cambridgeday.com
Stabbing in Central Square (and an Evidently False Police Report: August 3, 2020)

[NB: Please include this email as a communication to the City Council for
their next meeting. Thank you.]

August 18, 2020

Dear Mayor Siddiqui and City Council Members:

Two weeks ago this past Monday evening on August 3, at approximately 
7:30 p.m., someone I've known reasonably well for several years who lives
in Central Square was stabbed while sitting at a bench in front of Rodney's.
He had inadvertently sat down next to an apparently abandoned bag which
it turned out contained unopened bottles of beer and was first accosted and
then violently attacked by a total stranger.
Members of the CPD arrived and were informed by more than one person
that the assailant was "walking down the sidewalk." The police at the scene
reportedly did nothing to pursue or apprehend the assailant.
The victim was taken by ambulance to Mass General, where he received
stitches. He had apparently succeeded in partially blocking the knife blow
and, as a result, a second wound to his side was not especially deep.
Needless to say, however, contrary to the perhaps overly optimistic characterization
of this incident by the police in their CPD "Daily Log," any wound of this kind
could easily be life threatening.
It turns out that this person was also on blood thinner. He reported to me 
that he was bleeding rather profusely. This wanton assault could have obviously
been far worse than it was.
The police report for the Daily Log for August 3 states: "The suspect is believed
to be known to the victim."
According to the victim in question, this statement is completely false.
I ask you to consider the implications of this statement in an official police log.
Where would such a falsehood come from and why? (I'm afraid I have my own
suspicions.) Why was the suspect not pursued and possibly arrested?? Don't the
CPD want the citizenry to have highly accurate information regarding assaults
and other crimes in Central Square? Whose interests are being served when
this information is suppressed, or worse yet, presented in a manner that seemingly
attempts to minimize the "threat to the public" by demeaning the integrity of an
altogether innocent victim of a violent crime by a total stranger by insinuating that
"they knew each other," and hence it's presumably nothing for anyone else to be
particularly worried about??
I wonder if this false report shouldn't be investigated, but then I wonder, "Who

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

trhanscom <trhanscom@gmail.com>
Sunday, August 23, 2020 11:12 PM
City Clerk
FW: Council August 25 Agenda item: 5 Alternative Housing at Churchill Park. I request 
that the clerk include this letter/email in the agenda package.

Sent from my Samsung Galaxy smartphone.

-------- Original message --------
From: Tania Hanscom <trhanscom@gmail.com> 
Date: 2020-08-23 10:39 PM (GMT-05:00) 
To: mayor@cambridge.ca, adshades@cambridge.ca, reidd@cambridge.ca, devinem@cambridge.ca, 
mannm@cambridge.ca, liggettj@cambridge.ca, wolfp@cambridge.ca, ermetan@cambridge.ca 
Subject: Council August 25 Agenda item: 5 Alternative Housing at Churchill Park. I request that the clerk include this 
letter/email in the agenda package. 

Mayor and Council, City of Cambridge:

It came to my attention that city staff has prepared a report without public input on installing numerous pod 
type housing in Churchill park, Cambridge. This report is part of the council agenda for August 25th 2020 at 
10 am. Staff is seeking direction from the council to move forward with this proposal.

This is a very busy and well loved greenspace used by the citizens of Cambridge for sport and recreation. 
Bringing in any type of residences here is not acceptable or desirable. The park is surrounded by residential 
properties, schools, splash pads for kids, park, playground, as well as businesses.

The potential users who are planned to be housed in those pods are unknown and potentially a threat to the 
citizens who live in close proximity and to all users of churchill park.

The location of such a proposal is critical and I strongly suggest the council to vote against this location and 
direct staff to propose suitable locations together with public input from those locations prior to considering 
to vote for approval. I am against any housing projects inside this parkland.

I am flabbergasted that this was even put on the table by the very people who should be working for the hard 
working people in this city who contribute in so many ways,
Again, I request that the clerk include this letter/email in the agenda package.

Regards,
Tania Hanscom

Hello Councilors,

City Council

POR #147

I'm glad that the council is taking steps to acknowledge the urgency of addressing climate change through 
limiting/eliminating fossil fuels in new construction and preservation in Cambridge. While I admire the intent, my 
concern is that this doesn't go far enough to bring more efficient technologies and sustainable design to development 
projects.

The language should not include the assumption that "costs for different forms of clean energy are equal to or less than 
fossil fuels," because that's project-specific and provides a frame for developers that won't incentivize sustainable 
practices. If you do want to address costs as part of this PO, would be helpful to acknowledge that operating costs for 
this efficient tech are likely lower and/or more stable.

It's much more challenging to prescribe rehab measures, think this should focus on new construction opportunities. If 
very motivated to include rehab, would strongly recommend developing clearer guidance for rehab and new 
construction - e.g. consider adding insulating for gut rehabs, consider Passive House standards and compare common vs. 
unit metering approaches in new construction.

The sustainable technologies that may be considered in these studies vary greatly based on building size, type, and use:
new residential buildings < 10 units can be developed with no fossil fuel reliance much more easily than 100 unit 
buildings. Furthermore, residential and commercial buildings have vastly different needs for ventilation, utilities, etc.

Without including more detail on the measure you'd like developers to consider for categories of building types and 
uses, you'll see a range of studies framed to support their preferred tech. It's also important to acknowledge the cost of 
a WUFI model; would recommend that nonprofit developers have the option to pursue a more affordable analysis 
and/or can access grant funding for Green Building Projects.

I'm excited that the City is pursuing more aggressive action to make our built environment more carbon neutral. I hope
this PO can be an opportunity to set a higher standard, particularly for large new construction and commercial 
developments that have the biggest opportunity to make a more positive climate impact.

All my best,
Becca Schofield
ABC co-chair

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

James in Cambridge <tompaine@hotmail.com>
Thursday, September 10, 2020 6:50 AM
Clerk
heather.m.hoffman.1957@gmail.com
Communication to the City Council Re: Appointments to the CHA Board of 
Commissioners (9/10/20)

[Please include as a 'Communication' for Monday's City Council Meeting. Thanks.]

September 10, 2020

Dear Councillors,

I wonder why so many appointments to various boards and commissions
seem to turn into "lifetime appointments" in Cambridge?? Can it be that
difficult to find qualified citizens to "serve" in a city so rich in talent and
people eager to participate in civic life as Cambridge? What's the problem?
Please consider this unfortunate (and undemocratic) reality in weighing
renewal of appointments, especially any which involve persons who have
occupied positions for more than a decade. (Some just keep getting rolled
over forever!)

Please at least ask prospective appointees to the CHA Board the following:

1) What is your view regarding meaningful tenant participation at CHA?

2) Do you support public comment on announced agenda items

at CHA Board Meetings, as was once actually the case in Cambridge,
and is evidently the case today in neighboring cities like Somerville,
but not in Cambridge?

3) Do you support exploring the possibility for tenants in distinct

developments having the option of actually hiring the management 
companies or teams for their developments, as has been the case
apparently for years at some affordable housing developments in
Boston? And would you at least support the review of management
hires and promotions at CHA developments by the tenant community
in their respective developments??

Thank you for your consideration. 

Sincerely, James Williamson Jefferson Park

Cambridge, MA

1

Packet Pg. 396

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

James in Cambridge <tompaine@hotmail.com>
Thursday, September 10, 2020 5:07 AM
Clerk
heather.m.hoffman.1957@gmail.com; fritzdonov@aol.com; City Council
Communication to the City Council regarding the Community Preservation Act and CPA 
Funding & Formula

[Dear Anthony: Please include this as a Communication for the Council Meeting of 9/14/20.
Thanks.]

September 10, 2020

To the City Council:

Everyone knows that the distribution "formula" for CPA money will be 80-10-10
for so-called "affordable housing," as it has always been, but I feel obliged to send
a few remarks to our elected representatives nevertheless.
First of all, the online submission "form" used for comments does not allow one
to indicate an interest in more than just one category. Why is that?? Some of us
are interested in supporting all three.
And the form asks only if one is a "Resident or Business Owner." One could be both,
I suppose, but why are we being asked if we are "Residents" when the proponents
of 80-10-10 "for affordable," invariably work for and run the entities which ultimately
receive this funding, and are routinely allowed to testify at public hearings (and even
City Council meetings) without being required to provide their home addresses like the
rest of us?? A number of them live in leafy suburbs like Reading and Southborough,
but they love preaching "density" to those of us who live here! This seems profoundly 
disingenuous and hypocritical. We all know the annual CPA "process" is rigged, but
can't there be even a modicum of respect for those of us who actually do live in
Cambridge when it comes to deciding how to spend our own money?? It is, after all,
the "COMMUNITY - PRESERVATION - ACT," is it not??

[SOME COMMENTS ON THE CPA ALLOCATION FORMULA]

I am quite certain that nothing anyone says or writes will make the slightest bit of difference
to the decision about the CPA  allocation. I was an enthusiastic supporter of the Community Preservation Act, 
but would probably not vote for it again, primarily due to the anti-democratic nature of this “process,” and the 
fact - obvious to anyone with half a brain — that the “process”
is rigged. The recipients of the CPA money dutifully show up and “testify,” knowing they will soon be getting 
funds for their “non-profits” and their “mission” (and their payroll!), as if the outcome were ever in doubt. Is it 
really all that surprising that no one else do?? Lisa Peterson chaired the meeting and then, the very next day, 
joined the Affordable Housing Trust meeting and urged everyone there (the recipients of the money) to 
mobilize support for the 80-10-10 formula from which they benefit directly. There is scarcely any sign of 
embarrassment. The CHA reportedly circulated a “petition” of support at Lincoln Way and several other 
locations. No petitions were spontaneously circulated by anyone at Jefferson Park, where I live. One might ask, 

1

Packet Pg. 397

4.40.a

a
l
u
m
r

:

m

a
t
t

A

4.40.a

“Why not?” Apart from the fact that everyone here knows the result is a foregone conclusion, tenants of 
affordable housing are routinely left out of the picture when it comes to most of the decisions which affect 
our lives. Why support funding for something when your voices are routinely ignored?? “Just to have a roof 
over your head,” as someone who does NOT live in affordable housing recently opined. I can’t support 80-10-
10 “for affordable housing” anymore. Not without explicit commitments to lift up the voices of those who live 
in the housing that is to be funded, so, for example, management and management companies are re-
organized and re-directed to respect tenants and require full tenant participation. No one who “do” affordable 
housing EVER seem discuss how those of us who live in it are treated or feel about how we're treated.
Projects that are funded actually entail the reduction of practical open space. Deficits of open space should 
be compensated for with a comparable reduction in the funding for the so-called "affordable housing."
At Jefferson Park, a CPA-funded project involved the CHA's clear-cutting approximately 96 trees at the 
existing site. CHA now seek to destroy all the remaining brick buildings at Jefferson Park and to add 50 per 
cent additional “density.” (While they drive in from the suburbs!) How could anyone in his or her right mind 
countenance the destruction of their own homes in this
way, for these suburbanites?? Dozens and dozens of trees will be cut down if this plan is funded and allowed 
to go forward.
As if these predations were not bad enough, the cost of these so-called “affordable units” is as much as 
$528,000 a unit. (See the TDC per unit of the newly approved expansion at 402 Rindge Ave., already “pre-
approved” by the Affordable Housing Trust.) Lots of people are making lots of money, but WE’RE paying for it. 
This isn’t “COMMUNITY PRESERVATION,” this is a kind of organized gangsterism and pillage by people who 
know they know best and whose own spouses even, in some cases, are involved in the very same business. Is 
our money being squandered?
Condos in Reading, where the director of planning and development at the Housing Authority lives, who 
testified for the 80-10-10 without providing her home address, could be purchased for $460,000 each or less. 
I haven’t even mentioned the portion of the purported “Historic Preservation” allocation that actually goes to 
support officially-approved “affordable housing” projects.
The whole business is a sham and a scam, I'm sorry to say.
I support THE PUBLIC — AND PUBLICLY ACCOUNTABLE — PROVISION OF HOUSING!
I do NOT support THIS... I now recommend 40 per cent for "Housing," 20 percent for (actual)  "Historic 
Preservation," and 40 per cent for "Open Space," until such time as this process has been rendered more 
genuinely democratic, the authentic voices of tenants residing in affordable housing are truly heard, without 
prompting from their landlords, and the purposes of the Act are restored to what was originally intended: 
COMMUNITY PRESERVATION.

Sincerely, James M. Williamson

Cambridge, MA (not Reading, Southborough,
or any other "leafy suburb...")

A

Packet Pg. 415

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Elizabeth Gombosi <egombosi@gmail.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 12:24 PM
City Council; City Clerk
City Council September 14, 2020

Honorable Councillors:

I wish to speak today on two issues:

POR 2020 #188:

I strongly support the proposal to close several blocks in Harvard Square to vehicular traffic. This is 
an idea that has worked extremely well in other cities. Not only does it improve safety and support the 
business community, but it greatly enhances the experience of residents and visitors alike… 
something Harvard Square can use!

POR 2020 no # given in the agenda:

I strongly oppose passage of the 100% AHO as currently written. Some have said the issue has been 
discussed endlessly, but what was discussed was a former version of the ordinance and many of the 
important amendments to that version (such as protections for our tree canopy) have been dropped 
from the current version. There has been little discussion of critical amendments to the current 
version, nor of other options which would provide much more needed affordable housing.

The AHO ordinance was based largely on recommendations from builders and developers, who have 
financially supported the candidacy of some of the supporting councillors… that seems very 
questionable to me!

The AHO removes property owners’ rights.

The AHO removes vital design review from the Planning Board.

The AHO is a threat to the distinct characteristics of Cambridge neighborhoods, which make this city 
such an interesting place to live.

The AHO ignores critical components of the Envision document.

The AHO will promote discrimination by concentrating low-income residents in social ghettos.

The AHO provides no criteria to evaluate the success or failure of built projects.

The AHO is a poor proposal. Cambridge can and should do better!

Thank you,

Elizabeth Gombosi

42 Irving Street

1

City Council; Clerk
gather here has concerns - about a lot of things
LetterToCambridgeCouncil9_14_20.pdf

Attached is a letter outlining being left out of the process of reimagining Cambridge Street but also, not feeling like the 
City of Cambridge has supported the small business community in re-opening (as best we can) in light of a global 
pandemic. The City of Cambridge has been slower than our neighbors to create a consistent campaign and with so many 
businesses in the US closing FOREVER it behooves us to work together to help mend the fabric of our City.

Perez, Lori

Packet Pg. 420

Charles J. Marquardt 
10 Rogers Street Unit 1106 
Cambridge, MA 02142 

	
 
August 23, 2020 
 
 
To the Planning Board and City Council: 
 
I am writing to voice my support for BioMed Realty and the new development they have 
proposed for 585 Third Street. As the owner of Cambridge Spirits Dana Hill Liquors, small 
businesses that straddle Kendall and Central Squares, respectively, I believe it would benefit 
both of those areas- and the city as a whole. 
 
I look at the 585 Third Street proposal from the perspective of a small business owner. For 
retail shops like mine, an active and busy neighborhood is essential. We depend on foot 
traffic and visitors from nearby neighborhoods incorporating us into their routine as they 
pass through. That’s why I’m so excited about BioMed’s efforts to revitalize the Canal 
District in Kendall Square- more restaurants, arts, activations, and attractions will draw more 
people to this area and benefit not only my business but the many others in the vicinity. 
Some, especially bars and restaurants, have suffered under this pandemic even worse than 
Cambridge Spirits. 585 Third Street is the capstone to these efforts to transform the Canal 
District and would permanently transform the area into one much more inviting and 
accessible to all Cantabridgians. 
 
My shop is also on the doorstep of Central Square, and I have seen the toll that COVID is 
taking on that neighborhood- especially some beloved arts organizations, which were already 
in trouble before the pandemic. In my view, any expansion of the arts in Cambridge- let 
alone one as robust and diverse as the one BioMed is proposing- should be welcomed now 
more than ever. The arts are so important to a dynamic, attractive, exciting Cambridge which 
is the baseline for how businesses like mine can succeed. 
 
I hope you will vote in favor of the zoning needed to make this project a reality. I support it 
as a small business owner and know I speak for many others in the small retail world; but I 
also support it as someone who wants to see Cambridge continue to grow and come out of 
this pandemic stronger than ever. 
 
Thank you for your time, 
 

 
Charles J Marquardt 
Owner, Cambridge Spirits 
Owner, Dana Hill Liquors

A

	

Packet Pg. 421

Hello Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon, City Manager DePasquale, and esteemed members 
of the Cambridge City Council. 
 
My name is Kayleigh Kane, and I am a resident of Cambridge, and a proud member of the 
ImprovBoston community. I offer this testimony in support of the petition hosted by 
MASSCreative to advocate for protection and relief for arts and culture in Cambridge. 
 
I am a full-time artist and arts educator. As an ImprovBoston instructor and cast member of the 
ImprovBoston National Touring Company, I was making the majority of my income at or through 
this organization before the COVID-19 emergency. ImprovBoston has been one of the main 
contributors to my development as a performing artist, and as an arts educator, and I truly don’t 
know where I would be without it. 
 
One of the jobs I hold in the performing arts is as an Intimacy Director and Consent 
Professional. I work with groups of performing artists facilitate communication around consent, 
and help to ensure the mental and physical safety of artists as they perform moments of 
physical contact and sequences of simulated intimacy. As such, I have developed workshops 
for promoting consent and safety in Improv specifically, and ImprovBoston has been invaluable 
in the development and implementation of this curriculum. Because ImprovBoston prioritized the 
safety and well-being of their cast members and invested in these trainings, I believe we’re 
becoming a national leader in consensual improv. With IB’s help, I’ve now been able to start 
offering this training to improvisers at other theaters, and in other parts of the country. The 
adoption of this work, I believe, is central to making improv more safe and more inclusive 
around the world. ImprovBoston is at the forefront of that change. 
 
Since I moved to the greater Boston area in 2016, ImprovBoston has brought me to Central 
Square every single week. When I first joined the community, I would attend class once a week, 
and drop into a show most weekends. By 2020, I was rolling into ImprovBoston 5 or 6 times a 
week, every week. And with almost every trip to Central Square, I would visit another local 
business. The Green Goddess bowl at Life Alive has fueled many of my performances at 
ImprovBoston’s community-centered Harold Nights. Naco Taco is a favorite hang-out spot after 
a rehearsal. I’ve had countless meetings with ImprovBoston directors at 1369 Coffee House, 
and the students I teach at ImprovBoston have probably never seen me without one of their 
lemon ginger teas in hand. After shows, with my adrenaline still running high and needing to 
blow off steam, I head to the Field, or Zuzu’s, or Middle East, or 730. And I don’t think my 
boyfriend has ever attended a show without INSISTING we get Aleppo Palace takeout 
afterwards. 
 
I buy my plants at Central Square Florist, I get my art supplies in the basement of Artist and 
Craftsman Supply Cambridge, I get my records at Cheapo, and I get my exercise at the Dance 
Complex! And I would not have discovered any of these places - let alone made them my 
“usuals” - if I had not been pulled in by the loving and supportive community at ImprovBoston. 
 

4.45.a

n

A

Packet Pg. 422

Lastly, I want to speak briefly to the deeply positive impact ImprovBoston has on the countless 
lives it touches. As an instructor of both youth and adult classes, I have seen firsthand the 
unbridled joy improv brings at any age. I have seen children be positively transformed by their 
newfound confidence after making somebody laugh for the first time. Children who have been 
bullied at school, or who are struggling with a learning disability, or who are settling into a new 
foster home have all found a supportive and creative outlet in my ImprovBoston classroom. 
 
In my adult classes, I’ve taught introductory improv to parents, grandparents, college students, 
salespeople, HR professionals, construction workers, managers, circus performers, social 
workers, and engineers. And regardless of what age, background, profession, or personality 
type people walk into the room with, the one thing I hear from almost everybody is how grateful 
they are to be in a room where they can totally be themselves. Improv has helped me personally 
build stronger relationships with people in my life, encouraged me to be more confident and 
adventurous, and supported me through struggles with my mental health. This, and more, is 
what is brought to the lives of the hundreds and hundreds of people who come through the 
ImprovBoston Comedy School. Improv gives people a space to realize and express their 
creativity, to fully express big emotions, to improve their communication skills, and, of course, to 
laugh! 
 
And holy shit, do we need to laugh right now. 
 
Recently, in a virtual improv class, a new student joined the group in a round of uproarious 
laughter at a goofy story we had just worked together to tell. The new student then paused, and 
said “Oh my god, I think that was my first time laughing out loud in three months.” Comedy, in 
this time of uncertainty and great loss, has been an exercise in healing for so many. This has 
cemented my already-firm belief that our community in Cambridge needs ImprovBoston, and 
every ounce of the camaraderie, joy, and laughter it brings. 
 
I urge you, Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon, City Manager DePasquale, and Councillors, to 
adopt the policy recommendations set forth in the petition hosted by MASSCreative, to protect 
the future of arts and culture in the city of Cambridge. 
 
Thank you for your time, 
Kayleigh Kane

Packet Pg. 423

Kayleigh Kane <kayleigh.kane28@gmail.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 2:19 PM
City Clerk
City Council
Testimony for Today's City Council Meeting (5:30 PM)
Kayleigh Kane Testimony (Sept 14, 2020).pdf

I was hoping to speak at today's City Council meeting at 5:30 PM, on behalf of the petition hosted by MASSCreative. 
Unfortunately, I may not be able to attend, due to a work conflict, and I was wondering if I could submit my comments 
to be read aloud, on record, during the meeting?

Please let me know if this would be possible.

I have attached my testimony for the consideration of the esteemed Council members.

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:
Attachments:

Hi there,

Thank you very much,
Kayleigh Kane

---

September 14, 2020

Hello Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon, City Manager DePasquale, and esteemed members of the Cambridge City 
Council.

My name is Kayleigh Kane, and I am a resident of Cambridge, and a proud member of the ImprovBoston community. I 
offer this testimony in support of the petition hosted by MASSCreative to advocate for protection and relief for arts and 
culture in Cambridge.

I am a full-time artist and arts educator. As an ImprovBoston instructor and cast member of the ImprovBoston National 
Touring Company, I was making the majority of my income at or through this organization before the COVID-19 
emergency. ImprovBoston has been one of the main contributors to my development as a performing artist, and as an 
arts educator, and I truly don’t know where I would be without it.

One of the jobs I hold in the performing arts is as an Intimacy Director and Consent Professional. I work with groups of 
performing artists facilitate communication around consent, and help to ensure the mental and physical safety of artists 
as they perform moments of physical contact and sequences of simulated intimacy. As such, I have developed 
workshops for promoting consent and safety in Improv specifically, and ImprovBoston has been invaluable in the 
development and implementation of this curriculum. Because ImprovBoston prioritized the safety and well-being of 
their cast members and invested in these trainings, I believe we’re becoming a national leader in consensual improv. 
With IB’s help, I’ve now been able to start offering this training to improvisers at other theaters, and in other parts of 
the country. The adoption of this work, I believe, is central to making improv more safe and more inclusive around the 
world. ImprovBoston is at the forefront of that change.

Since I moved to the greater Boston area in 2016, ImprovBoston has brought me to Central Square every single week. 
When I first joined the community, I would attend class once a week, and drop into a show most weekends. By 2020, I 

1

A

4.45.b

was rolling into ImprovBoston 5 or 6 times a week, every week. And with almost every trip to Central Square, I would 
visit another local business. The Green Goddess bowl at Life Alive has fueled many of my performances at 
ImprovBoston’s community-centered Harold Nights. Naco Taco is a favorite hang-out spot after a rehearsal. I’ve had 
countless meetings with ImprovBoston directors at 1369 Coffee House, and the students I teach at ImprovBoston have 
probably never seen me without one of their lemon ginger teas in hand. After shows, with my adrenaline still running 
high and needing to blow off steam, I head to the Field, or Zuzu’s, or Middle East, or 730. And I don’t think my boyfriend 
has ever attended a show without INSISTING we get Aleppo Palace takeout afterwards.

I buy my plants at Central Square Florist, I get my art supplies in the basement of Artist and Craftsman Supply 
Cambridge, I get my records at Cheapo, and I get my exercise at the Dance Complex! And I would not have discovered 
any of these places - let alone made them my “usuals” - if I had not been pulled in by the loving and supportive 
community at ImprovBoston.

Lastly, I want to speak briefly to the deeply positive impact ImprovBoston has on the countless lives it touches. As an 
instructor of both youth and adult classes, I have seen firsthand the unbridled joy improv brings at any age. I have seen 
children be positively transformed by their newfound confidence after making somebody laugh for the first time. 
Children who have been bullied at school, or who are struggling with a learning disability, or who are settling into a new 
foster home have all found a supportive and creative outlet in my ImprovBoston classroom.

In my adult classes, I’ve taught introductory improv to parents, grandparents, college students, salespeople, HR 
professionals, construction workers, managers, circus performers, social workers, and engineers. And regardless of what 
age, background, profession, or personality type people walk into the room with, the one thing I hear from almost 
everybody is how grateful they are to be in a room where they can totally be themselves. Improv has helped me 
personally build stronger relationships with people in my life, encouraged me to be more confident and adventurous, 
and supported me through struggles with my mental health. This, and more, is what is brought to the lives of the 
hundreds and hundreds of people who come through the ImprovBoston Comedy School. Improv gives people a space to 
realize and express their creativity, to fully express big emotions, to improve their communication skills, and, of course, 
to laugh!

And holy shit, do we need to laugh right now.

Recently, in a virtual improv class, a new student joined the group in a round of uproarious laughter at a goofy story we 
had just worked together to tell. The new student then paused, and said “Oh my god, I think that was my first time 
laughing out loud in three months.” Comedy, in this time of uncertainty and great loss, has been an exercise in healing 
for so many. This has cemented my already-firm belief that our community in Cambridge needs ImprovBoston, and 
every ounce of the camaraderie, joy, and laughter it brings.

I urge you, Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon, City Manager DePasquale, and Councillors, to adopt the policy 
recommendations set forth in the petition hosted by MASSCreative, to protect the future of arts and culture in the city 
of Cambridge.

Thank you for your time,
Kayleigh Kane

Eric Holmberg <ejhberg@gmail.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 2:34 PM
City Council
Clerk
9/14 Council Meeting Public Comment re:City Manager

To whom it may concern,

I am writing to submit a public comment for this evening's Council meeting.

I strongly oppose extending the City Manager's contract for any longer than one year. He has not taken seriously the 
needs of Cambridge residents--especially broadband, housing, and public safety without police. I do not have faith that 
we can make real progress on these pressing issues without a change in the office of City Manager.

Furthermore, I encourage the Council not to extend the City Manager's contract beyond its current end date.

Sincerely,
Eric Holmberg
238 Columbia St #1W
Cambridge, MA 02139
