Packet Pg. 426

9/14/2020	

Dear	Mayor	and	Councilors,	

I	am	writing	for	the	Cambridge	Residents	Alliance	regarding	Policy Order #8 (POR 2020 #198) on 
tonight’s agenda regarding	extension	of	the	city	manager’s	contract. 

The	city	council	has	had	to	delay	addressing	many	important	issues	to	deal	with	the	coronavirus	
pandemic,	including	the	manager’s	request	to	extend	his	contract.		Since	the	Council	has	to	reply	to	the	
manager	soon,	we	ask	that	the	council	extend	the	contract	for	one	year	only,	with	an	option	to	extend	
the	contract	for	an	additional	6-12	months	if	needed.		We	think	that	is	preferable	to	the	18	months	
proposed	by	Councilor	Simmons	(COF	2020	#46.)	

We	also	ask	that	the	Council	decide	on	a	process	to	evaluate	the	manager,	and	begin	that	evaluation	as	
soon	as	possible.	Initially	the	Council	could	evaluate	the	manager	using	the	most	recent	Council	goals,	
including	criteria	for	success,	and	require	a	means	of	public	input.		Longer-term,	the	Council	should	
design	a	more	comprehensive	evaluation,	such	as	is	outlined	in	“Evaluating	the	City	Manager	Best	
Management	Practices,”	http://fccma.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Evaluating-the-City-
Manager.pdf	.	

That	document	notes	that	a	comprehensive	manager	evaluation	provides	feedback,	demonstrates	
accountability	to	residents,	and	maintains	alignment	between	goals	and	accomplishments.	The	
evaluation	should	address	1)	results	that	should	be	accomplished,	and	the	extent,	efficiency	and	
effectiveness	with	which	specific	established	goals	and	expectations	can	be	tracked	to	determine	
success,	and	2)	a	wide	range	of	leadership	skills	that	should	be	demonstrated.	
	
The	document	recommends	that	the	Council	adopt,	after	getting	public	input,	an	organizational	Vision,	
Mission,	Goals	and	Objectives	that	can	be	objectively	tracked	to	determine	progress/success	as	part	of	
the	performance	review	process.		It	also	recommends	that	“the	city	manager	complete	a	self-evaluation,	
providing	elected	officials	the	process	by	which	he/she	pursued	organizational	and	individual	goals,	and	
the	perceptions	of	both	the	Manager	and	stakeholders	of	his/her	success	or	failure	in	meeting	those	
goals	during	the	review	period.”	

In	addition	to	working	on	the	evaluation	of	the	manager	and	designing	a	comprehensive	manager	
evaluation,	we	ask	that	the	Council	establish	a	process	and	timing	for	a	nation-wide	city	manager	search	
and	hiring	process.		That	process	should	include	a	national	salary	survey.		The	city’s	search	for	a	school	
superintendent	could	inform	the	search	for	a	city	manager.	
	
At	a	public	meeting	of	the	Cambridge	Residents	Alliance	in	early	2020,	many	members	of	the	public	
expressed	dissatisfaction	with	the	lack	of	evaluation	of	the	manager,	and	expressed	concerns	about	
specific	aspects	of	his	performance.		Residents	were	unhappy	that	too	many	times	the	manager	has	not	
responded	at	all	to	the	Council’s	repeated	policy	orders,	or	has	responded	very	slowly.		Residents	
expressed	dissatisfaction	with	the	development	model	that	this	and	prior	managers	have	used,	which	
includes	permitting	substantial	commercial	development	in	order	to	generate	tax	revenue.		
	
Other	areas	of	concern	include	the	lack	of	manager’s	dialogue	with	the	council	about	not	responding	to	
policy	orders,	and	the	fact	that	he	has	over-ruled	some	policies.	These	concerns	also	include	the	
manager’s	initial	refusal	to	start	a	broadband	feasibility	study,	extending	the	ban	on	re-usable	bags,	
slowness	to	increase	funding	for	affordable	housing,	delays	on	implementing	Shared	Streets,	and	the	
lack	of	transparency	on	Covid	task	force	meetings.

Marlene Lundberg <mlundber59@gmail.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 5:01 PM
City Council
City Clerk
Term of City Manager and Better Planning and Zoning

I support a thorough, formal, and open evaluation of the City Manager, based on the stated goals of the 
council.
I favor granting a one-year contract only.   I would like to see some new blood in the city management. 

 I would like to see the following:
- better planning for the future, 
- more carefully considered zoning,
- preservation of some historic urban plans [East Cambridge Urban Plan], and
- an end to developers trading affordable housing In order to break height limits, or other existing limits. 

I also want to mention that I have the impression that several of the speakers at City Council during the 

4.
hearings for the CambridgeSide petition in 2019 spoke with little passion and seemed to 

have received some inducement(s) to appear on behalf of N.E.D.   This is an impression, not an 
assertion, as I have no proof.

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Dear Councillors,

Jennifer Storozum <jsstoroz@gmail.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 5:19 PM
City Council
Clerk
City Manager Contract Renewal and Charter Review

I would like to state my opinion that City Manager DePasquale's contract should be extended by as little time as possible 
or perhaps not renewed at all. He has not demonstrated the kind of progressive leadership that is expected from a city 
like Cambridge.

Fellow Cantabridgian Chris Schmidt lays out some data on his blog post:

At the end of the 2017 Council session, more than 35 items awaiting report from the City Manager — some 
dating back more than 18 months — were simply “placed on file” after a lack of response from the Manager, 
and this is by no means atypical.  
[...]
Throughout 2017, 7 different policy orders were filed seeking information on the current status of the City on 
moving forward on the recommendations of the Municipal Broadband Task Force — none received a 
response.

When residents asked for a copy of the Cambridge Police Department's annual report to the City Manager and an 
inventory of police equipment, the Manager should have had these in hand as stipulated by the Department's 
requirement to submit an annual report. Yet it was nowhere to be found.

Every employee I know is submitted to a yearly, if not more frequent, performance review by their employer where they 
are measured against an explicit rubric or framework that allows employers to assess whether the employee has been 
doing a good job. Where is the City Manager's performance review? On what basis is his performance evaluated?

If I had ignored requests for 35 different reports at my job, like the City Manager has, my manager would certainly be 
calling me in for a chat or have me put on a Performance Improvement Plan or perhaps fire me on the spot.

City Manager is a position with an enormous amount of power in Cambridge, and we must hold that power to account. 
Please do not vote to extend the City Manager's contract by 24 months.

The time is ripe to look at our city charter with a critical eye and see if there is not a way to improve our government's 
accountability and transparency.

Thank you,
Jae Storozum
16 Whittier St

4.51.a

Packet Pg. 433

Christopher Schmidt <crschmidt@crschmidt.net>
Monday, September 14, 2020 5:57 PM
City Council; Clerk
On the City Manager's Contract Renewal

In my opinion, the City Manager needs to demonstrate greater accountability to the Council and the Public in order to 
earn a long-term renewal of his contract. Given that he has been nonresponsive to repeated orders from the Council, 
even with demonstrated broad support, and has actively misled the council on important elements of fact in response to 
Council demands, I believe that a careful evaluation of the City Manager's work is due -- and sorely lacking.

I would encourage you to keep this in mind as you consider his contract renewal this evening.

(I meant to include this in my public comment, but I spaced out and forgot; forgive me.)

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Members of the Council,

All the best,
Christopher Schmidt

Packet Pg. 435

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Patrick Magee <pmag123@gmail.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 3:44 PM
City Council; City Clerk
9/14/20 City Council Meeting agenda thoughts

Madam Mayor and Councilors,
I wanted to share my personal thoughts on some of the business before you tonight. Given the scope of the agenda, I 
will comment on them in order and I will try to be brief. 
Charter Right 2 
There are currently 56 items on the awaiting reports list. Does the council really want to ask the manager to spend time 
investigating this? I can only imagine that in addition to the probable legal issues, the logistical, personnel, and union 
issues would make this amazingly complicated and unlikely to come to fruition. It seems like passage would only 
generate unnecessary work for the administration, while not addressing the need for ensuring equity in the 
enforcement of traffic laws throughout the city.
Charter Right 3
I would happily support anything that would increase the ease and likelihood of a high voter turnout in Cambridge. It is 
the cornerstone of our constitutional republic.
Applications and Petitions 2
I don't believe that the applicant has reached out to ISNA yet. I think that the council should hear their opinion before 
making a decision.
Applications and Petitions 3
I am in full support of BioMed Realty's zoning petition. I believe it will carry forward the spirit of the constellation center 
which will benefit the area.
Policy Order 4
While I think that there are potential merits to the spirit of this order, I am concerned because I don't believe that the 
HSBA was engaged prior to or during the drafting. I have heard all of you state multiple times that you are concerned 
with protecting small businesses. Unfortunately, there seems to be a tendency to not reach out to constituent groups 
that are bound to be affected, before putting in policy orders. I just wanted to point this out and once again ask you all 
to seek out and respect our opinions. It has been hard feeling ignored, especially give the additional challenges that the 
Covid-19 pandemic has presented to the small business community.
Committee Report 2
I believe that I have made my feelings abundantly clear about the CSO. I truly hope that you will opt to remove 
Cambridge Street from this restrictive and prescriptive ordinance. Leaving it in will almost definitely result in an outcome 
that a handful of you have publicly stated would be disappointing. While deciding what actions you will take tonight, 
please consider how you would be feeling about this if it had been an administration driven process, instead of a council 
driven process. Would any of you as individuals been comfortable with the near complete lack of public process? I have 
heard almost all of you clearly state the importance of public process and vocally complain when city staff haven't 
executed outreach to your standards. I am simply asking that you hold yourselves to that same standard. 
Additionally, I feel the need to set the record straight. This morning, Cambridge Bicycle Safety sent out an email to 
generate support for passage of the CSO. Their email included the line "However, there has been lobbying behind the 
scenes to remove Cambridge St. from the ordinance . . . . . (sic)" In my opinion, this is an outrageous display of gas 
lighting. 
The reality is that members of Cambridge Bicycle Safety and the City Council, met behind closed doors to draft the 
ordinance, with no input from anyone else else. The ECBA has sent letters that are a part of the public record to voice 
our concerns. After the PO was taken off the table, we reached out to all of you collectively and individually to attempt 
to find a solution that would be palatable to all parties. Additionally, I reached out directly to the Cambridge Bicycle 
Safety in an effort to find common ground. Unfortunately, Cambridge Bicycle Safety chose to spread a complete lie, 

1

A

4.54.a

which will ultimately only dive a wedge deeper between different groups. It is disappointing and disheartening that they 
are choosing to conduct themselves this way.
Committee Report 3 
I am supportive of the AHO and I am thankful for the amendment to protect active first floor space. I did want to point 
out that I believe that there is a potential problem with the two year look back in that amendment. Two sites come to 
mind quickly that this would impact. The Sunset Cafe site at 851 Cambridge Street, caught fire in January of 2019, so we 
are less than 4 months away from the two year cap. Additionally, the University Monument Works, at 1055 Cambridge 
Street has been vacant for over three years. Losing first floor retail on either of these sites would negatively impact the 
commercial corridor. Please work to remedy this potential issue.
Committee Report 4
I fully support extending the City Manager's contract for 24 months. Given the ongoing challenges presented by the 
Covid-19 crisis, consistency is incredibly important. Having actively participated in the most recent City Manager 
selection process, I find it unlikely that we as a community will be able to engage in the public process necessary to chart 
a new course of our community that this hire will signify, if we try to rush things. The city is in great hands under the 
leadership of Mr DePasquale and we should utilize his experience while we work collaboratively through this important 
transition. 
Committee Report 5
Lastly, I fully support the appointment of Louis Bacci, III to the Cambridge Housing Authority Board. 
Thank you for your service,

--
Patrick Magee
Owner, Atwood's Tavern
President, East Cambridge Business Association

Packet Pg. 437

Kathy Watkins <kathywatkins@mac.com>
Monday, September 14, 2020 4:03 PM
City Council
Clerk
Policy Order #8 (POR 2020 #198.)

Welcome back after a summer unlike any we have experienced! I appreciate your work during this time of pandemic and 
upheaval.

I am writing today regarding Policy Order #8 (POR 2020 #198.) regarding an extension of the City Manager's contract. 
Please give the manager a one-year contract Extension with the option of a 6-12 month further extension. In a previous 
meeting, the majority of the council seemed to be opposed to the longer 2 year contract. 

In addition I hope you institute a detailed plan to evaluate the manager based on the goals of the city.

Perez, Lori

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Dear Councilors,

Thank you. 

Sincerely,
Kathy Watkins
90 Fawcett St #511
Cambridge, MA 02138
617-275-6833

Although Louise DePesquale has worked diligently through the years to serve the city, many Cambridge residents 
believe we need a new manager who will more closely follow the policy goals of you, our elected officials. We also need 
a thorough evaluation f the manager based on the goals of the council.

1

Packet Pg. 440

 

TO: council@cambridgema.gov, clerk@cambidgema.gov 

Monday 14Sep20 530pm Cambridge City Council Meeting 

I’m Fritz Donovan, 42 Irving Street, Cambridge. 

Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon, Councilors –  

Policy Order #4 which proposes to close a few blocks of Harvard Square streets 

to cars is exactly the kind of innovative change we need to add new Covid-safe 

space for outdoor seating and retail and help Harvard Square work its way back 

to the kind of socially and economically successful destination it used to be.  

This idea has already proved effective in several other major cities around the 

country and should be implemented in Cambridge as quickly as possible.  Please 

give it your strong support. 

As to the 100% Affordable Housing Overlay ordinance, I enthusiastically endorse 

your heroic efforts over the last year or two to negotiate a fair and workable plan 

to increase the amount of affordable housing in Cambridge.  But I am deeply 

disappointed that so many wise and well-drafted enhancements agreed to in your 

hundreds of hours of debate and discussion last session are not included in the 

ordinance language before you tonight.  Cambridge clearly needs more 

affordable housing, but all residents of this historic city deserve a balanced 

approach to fill that need.  And our planet simply begs for relief from the forces 

that are rapidly shrinking our vital tree canopy and open spaces that benefit every 

resident of every economic level in our already dense city.  The horrific wildfires 

on the west coast, the increasingly violent storms which are now commonplace 

everywhere and the melting of glaciers dramatically raising our ocean levels are 

just the first harbingers of what we all face if we do not take our obligations to 

this planet seriously.   As one pundit put so perfectly: “If we do not, the next 

endangered species - is us.”  I hope you will take time to add back in at least 

some of last year’s vital environment amendments before adopting this 

ordinance.   We – and the planet - are counting on you. 

4.57.b

Wilson, Anthony
Tuesday, September 15, 2020 11:24 AM
Perez, Lori
FW: City Council:  Santander Projecting Sign, Central Sq., App. 1 (2020 #32), 9/14/20
20200911_132457.jpg; 20200911_132851.jpg; 20200911_132942.jpg; 20200911_
133038.jpg; 20200911_133145.jpg; 20200911_133254.jpg; 20200911_133424 (2).jpg; 
20200911_133931.jpg

From: Carol O'Hare <cbo1066@gmail.com> 
Sent: Saturday, September 12, 2020 11:14 AM
To: City Council <CityCouncil@CambridgeMA.GOV>
Cc: Wilson, Anthony <awilson@cambridgema.gov>
Subject: City Council: Santander Projecting Sign, Central Sq., App. 1 (2020 #32), 9/14/20

Dear Mayor Siddiqui, Vice Mayor Mallon and City Councillors:

Sure! This is way down on everyone’s priority list, BUT …
- Enough already! The 8 Central Square banks are already plenty “SIGNED UP.”   Indeed, some are screaming: Look 
Here > Look Here More >  No, Look Only Here!
See attached bank-photos, West to East, 4 short blocks.
- These 8 banks’ many existing signs already distract from Central Sq.’s fabulous murals, retail stores’ signs and eclectic 
architecture. Especially so, now that so many retail businesses and restaurants are folding.
- Yes, the Council has already approved 2 of the 8 banks’ projecting signs!
- But, that’s no justification for approving Santander’s now. Mass Ave. and adjacent sidewalks are our public way and 
air rights, not the bank$’. No one’s entitled to use our public way to advertise, least of all banks that are overwhelming 
our once vibrant Central Square.

Please just stop favoring banks with the privilege of protruding into our public way & air rights. 

Central Square – Mass Ave., 8 Banks, 4 blocks (Photos attached)
1. Bank of America Financial Center - #727
2. Citizens Bank - #689 - Existing 2 huge, projecting signs
3. Leader Bank - #675
4. Eastern Bank - #647
5. Cambridge Savings Bank - #630 – Existing 2 small, projecting sign
6. TD Bank - #617
7. Santander Bank - #599 - Next Up?
8, People’s United Bank - #485

*Yes, Santander’s proposed projecting sign is smaller than those the Council has already permitted.

But, especially now with more local businesses disappearing, please: Just say “no” more!

Thanks, as always, for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

Carol O’Hare
172 Magazine St.

Cc: Anthony Wilson, City Clerk - Please file this with the Official Record.

Dear City Council, 

June <junerun@gmail.com>
Sunday, September 13, 2020 11:56 PM
City Clerk
Danroy DJ Henry Resolution 

I want to send deep heartfelt appreciation for the Resolution presented tonight requesting the reopening of the Case for 
Danroy DJ Henry and am grateful to Cambridge City Council leaders, Marc McGovern, Sumbul Siddiqui, Denise Simmons, 
Quinton Zondervan and others for their support of this Resolution. 

We all know (or are now realizing) “DJ Henry” could easily be the son we have sent off to college. I thank you for holding 
the officer involved in stepping in front of and shooting into a car full of students accountable for his reckless and 
dangerous actions. 

With great hopes for the future, 

June Parks
CRLS Alumni, Class of ‘88

Packet Pg. 456

                                                                                                                              608 Huron Ave. 
                                                                                                                              Cambridge, MA 02138 
                                                                                                                               jatttanucci@gmail.com 
 

July 24, 2020 

Dear Cambridge City Councilors: 

      The City’s Transit Advisory Committee met virtually on July 8, 2020 to review and discuss the 
proposed ordinance amending the “Cycling Safety Ordinance”. We understand that this proposed 
ordinance amendment is to be voted on by the City Council as early as the summer Council meeting in 
late July 2020. While the Committee generally agreed with the intent and overall thrust of the 
ordinance, the Committee wanted to express a few concerns with the ordinance as it is currently 
written. Below, we suggest several changes to ensure that the City analyzes the changes to streets with 
both cyclists and bus riders in mind and that bus riders in the City are not unduly delayed by the changes 
that implementation of this ordinance would bring about on City streets.  

       When allocating precious street space in the City, the Committee feels that it is important to 
remember that the clear plurality of people on the street on major bus corridors such as Massachusetts 
Ave. and Mt. Auburn St. are on the bus. Many bus riders simply cannot or will not ride bikes, others have 
disabilities that make riding the bus the most comfortable and safe. In addition, large proportions of bus 
riders are members of under-represented minority groups who depend on public transportation for the 
majority of their trips to, from, and within Cambridge. Our buses in Cambridge also attract a wide range 
of “choice” riders that have historically chosen to ride the bus for a variety of reasons even though they 
generally have access to other means of transportation. Some of these riders chose the bus to save 
money, sometimes save time, for their own personal impact on climate change, stay out of bad weather, 
or because they feel safest while riding with others on a bus. We hope that the City Council recognizes 
this substantial group of street users during your deliberations and carefully evaluate and assess 
whether any unintentional consequences of the Cycling Safety Ordinance could potentially cause 
unacceptable delays to bus riders. 

      In this spirit, the Committee would like to offer the following specific amendments to the ordinance, 
as it is currently drafted, for careful consideration by the Council: 

1. 

2. 

In paragraph H of Section 12.22.030, amend the definition of “Public Transportation” to include 
the word “routes” as well as “stops” as follows: “shall mean bus and shuttle routes and stops”; 
In Section 12.22.040, paragraph B, insert a new phrase in the second sentence as follows (in 
italics): “Full compliance with the provisions of Subsection A above will be considered 
impracticable only in those rare circumstances where the City Manager determines that the 
characteristics of the physical features or usage of a street, a demonstrable negative impact on a 
Public Transportation route’s travel times and/or other service quality factors will result from full 
compliance, or financial constraints of full compliance prevent the incorporation of a Permanent 
Separated Bicycle Lane with Adequate Directionality.” 

 

 

 

4.61.c

Packet Pg. 457

3. 

In Section 12.22.040, paragraph E, insert the following phrase (in italics) in the first sentence: 
“By no later than May 1, 2021, the City Manager shall submit to the City Council a block-by-block 
analysis determining the impacts, including the potential travel time and/or other service quality 
impacts for Public Transportation riders of installing Temporary Traffic Control Device Separated 
Bicycle Lanes and or Quick-Build Separated Bicycle Lanes on:” 

4.  Any other amendments that the Council may deem appropriate consistent with the above 

changes and the intent of not diminishing, but improving, the riding experience and travel time 
of bus riders throughout the City. 

      The Committee appreciates the opportunity to comment on this proposed ordinance and hopes that 
the City Council will seriously consider these recommendations. 

Sincerely, 

 
John Attanucci on behalf of the Transit Advisory Committee 
Chair, Transit Advisory Committee 
 

c.c., Andrew Reker, Assistant Transportation Planner, CCD

Packet Pg. 854

5.1

R-1 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of longtime Cambridge 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

resident John Pedro Ramos on July 6, 2020; and  
 
John Ramos was born on November 11, 1934, and throughout his life he was always 
driven to improve the world around him, serving as a community activist well into his 
golden years; and  
 
John Ramos was a proud founding member of the Senior Advisory Committee that 
was convened by then-Mayor E. Denise Simmons in 2008, and among the many 
projects he was proudest of was his collaborating with the MBTA to place a covered 
bus shelter near the LBJ Apartment on Erie Street, so that the senior residents who 
utilized that stop would have some protection from the elements; and  
 
John Ramos also worked tirelessly with the MBTA and the local taxi companies to be 
more mindful of the needs of their senior patrons, and his good work, and gentle 
manner; continues to live on, and he shall be very much missed throughout the 
Cambridge community that he was such a large part of; now therefore be it  
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council formally go on record in extending its deepest condolences to 
the family and friends of John Ramos for their loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to the family of John Ramos on behalf of the entire City Council. 

Packet Pg. 855

 

 

5.1

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;  
 
 
 
ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 

Packet Pg. 856

5.2

R-2 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Fr. George D. 

Vartzelis, former pastor at Sacred Heart in Cambridge, on August 16, 2020 at the age 
of 92; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  George D. Vartzelis, was born in Beverly, MA on April 29, 1928 to Louis D. and 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

Catherine D. (Rena Cravatis) Vartzelis, he grew up in Beverly and graduated from St. 
Joseph Académie in Salem in 1946, he entered St. John’s Seminary in Brighton, and he 
was ordained a priest at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston by Archbishop 
Richard Cushing on September 29, 1953; and 
 
Fr. George D. Vartzelis served the faithful in many Massachusetts parishes over the 
decades, including assignments to St. Anne in Littleton (1953), Our Lady of the Lake 
in Monponsett (1955), All Saints in Roxbury (1955), St. Joseph in Lynn (1960), St. 
Agnes in Reading (1964), St. Matthias in Marlboro (1971), St. Margret in Dorchester 
(1971), and he was then assigned as pastor at Sacred Heart in Cambridge (1975), 
Sacred Heart in Roslindale (1984), St. Thomas Aquinas in Nahant (1990), and St. 
James the Great in Wellesley (1997); and   
 
Fr. George D. Vartzelis also served as a chaplain in the U.S. Navy Reserve (1961 – 
1975), he served as the first Director of Personnel for the Boston Archdiocese in the 
1970s for eight years, and he retired in 2003 upon completing his assignment at St. 
James the Great; and  
 

on the lives of his family and friends, and to the many parishioners he ministered to 
during his years of pastoral service, he was greatly loved by all those he served, he 
shall always be remembered for his boundless devotion to his work and his loved ones, 
and for his unfailing zest for life and sense of humor; and  
 
Fr. George D. Vartzelis was an avid and voracious reader and a devoted student of 
history, he enjoyed listening to classical music and attending concerts by the Boston 
Symphony Orchestra, as well as traveling across the country and throughout the world; 
and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  A very gracious and generous man, Fr. George D. Vartzelis made a significant impact 

Packet Pg. 857

5.2

WHEREAS: 

In addition to his deceased parents Louis and Catherine, Fr. George D. Vartzelis leaves 
his sister Gloria Melanson, wife of Noel Melanson (both deceased) and his brother 
Theodore and his wife Cynthia (both deceased), his nephew Douglas Melanson and his 
nieces Leigh Melanson-Adams, Kathleen (Melanson) Faigen and Janis Melanson and 
their spouses, and niece Deborah Vartzelis, he also leaves several cousins and grand- 
nieces and nephews, and his memory shall be forever cherished by all; now therefore 
be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council formally go on record extending its deepest sympathy to the 

family of Fr. George D. Vartzelis for their tremendous loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to Douglas Melanson, nephew of Fr. George D. Vartzelis, on behalf of 
the entire City Council. 

 

 

 

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;  
 
 
 
ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 

Packet Pg. 858

 
 
 

 

 

 

 

 

5.3

R-3 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Kevin Kerrigan on 

August 27, 2020 at the age of 80; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Kevin Kerrigan was the devoted husband of 52 years to the late Janice (Pender) 

Kerrigan, and he leaves behind his children: Sean J. Kerrigan and his wife, Jill Ashton, 
of Clinton, Susan J. Reardon and her husband, John, and Stephen J. Kerrigan and his 
husband, Jacob Watts, all of Lancaster, four grandchildren: Emily, Natalie, Kevin and 
Finbar; one great-grandchild, Adalyn, two brothers: Paul Kerrigan and his wife, 
Marion, of Franklin, and James Kerrigan and his wife, Patricia, of Clinton, and many 
nieces and nephews, and his memory shall be forever cherished by all who knew him; 
now therefore be it  
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council go on record extending its deepest condolences to the family of 

Kevin Kerrigan at this time of such personal loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to Steve Kerrigan and the Kerrigan Family on behalf of the entire City 
Council. 

In City Council September 14, 2020.

Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE

COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened at learning of the death of William “Bill” 

Michael Reghitto on August 11, 2020; and  
 

 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill was born on June 3, 1942; and 
 
WHEREAS:  Bill was the devoted son of Florence and Louis; and  
 
WHEREAS:  Bill was the loving husband of Judith for fifty years; and  
 
WHEREAS:  Bill was raised in North Cambridge, attended the Cambridge Public Schools, and was a 

 

 

graduate of Bentley College; and  
 

 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill received an MBA from Boston College; and   
 
WHEREAS:   Bill spent two years working at IBM in Kingston, New York and then began a thirty-
year career in commercial banking services at State Street Bank in Boston, beginning 
as a credit analyst in 1969; and retiring as an Executive Vice President of Commercial 
Banking Services in 1999; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill was a consummate professional known for his business sense, ethics, and instincts;  

he was known for his philanthropy and shared his time and business expertise with 
many charitable organizations over the years, including St. Augustine's Church in 
Andover (Finance Committee); Abenaqui Country Club (Board of Governors – 
Treasurer); Catholic Charities; and the Boston Symphony Orchestra (A Company 
Christmas at the Pops where he performed Sleigh Ride on stage at Symphony Hall); 
and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill served professionally on the Board of Directors and as a Member of the Executive 

Committee at Brewster Wallpaper, Harr Auto Group, and BDC Capital; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill was given the opportunity, during his retirement, to join a thoroughbred horse 

racing ownership group, through which he was able to travel and watch his horses race 
at tracks across the country; and 
 

Packet Pg. 868

5.9

WHEREAS:  Bill especially enjoyed annual family trips to Saratoga Springs, New York every 

August;  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill fulfilled a lifelong dream in 2019 when he watched one of his horses, Vekoma, 

race in the Kentucky Derby; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill, who was also known by those who love him as William, Billy and Gramps, will 
be remembered for his generosity, and his love of family and friends, fireworks, and 
morning rides to the beach; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill’s passing will leave a void in the lives of all his surviving family; his beloved 

children Allison, Brad, Heather and her husband Jason, Matthew and his partner, Ziggy 
and her son Dimitri; his cherished granddaughter Lilah; and many other loving 
relatives and friends; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Bill will be sorely missed by all he touched and loved; now therefore be it 
 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council go on record extending its deepest sympathy for the family of 

 

William Michael Reghitto at this time of such personal loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to the Reghitto family on behalf of the entire City Council. 

 

 

 

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;  
 
 
 
ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Leon West on August 

21, 2020 at the age of 74; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Leon Richard West was born in Cambridge in 1946 to the late Harold West and 

 
WHEREAS: 

Dorothy Rose, as one of eight children he was raised in the Washington Elms section 
of the city, and as a young man he first developed his passion for working in the 
restaurant industry, starting in 1962 when he began working first at Jonny’s Diner, as a 
busboy and dishwasher, and at Mahlowitz Market, where he learned to estimate and 
place large produce orders and keep accurate inventories; and  
 
From these formulative experiences, Leon West set out to pursue a career as a chef, 
attending the Massachusetts Vocational and Technical School’s Culinary Arts 
Program, receiving his on-the-job training at the Sheraton Hotel in Boston, and 
becoming an expert on the many cuisines this world has to offer; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Leon West – or “Chef Leon,” as he was universally and affectionately known to his 

friends and admirers –  moved to New Orleans in 1984 with his wife and seven 
daughters, and he was quickly recognized among his peers, both locally and 
internationally, as one of the city’s most talented chefs, as an innovative and versatile 
creator, and his menus have pleased guests at small elegant dinners and at functions for 
over 12,000 attendees; and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Leon West was inducted into the African American Chef’s Hall of Fame in 1997, and 

his biography there notes that his “…outstanding characteristics…are dedication, 
willingness to create the extraordinary under extreme pressure, and being well versed 
in every aspect of cooking”; and 
 

Packet Pg. 872

5.11

WHEREAS:  Leon West was preceded in death by his wife, Joyce Ann Newson West, his daughter 
Sonya Marie West, and his sister Constance Smith, and he leaves behind his children 
Linda Perreira, Jessie Perreira, Sabrina Newson King (and husband Craig L. King), 
Robert L. DeRosa (and wife Joyce DeRosa), Sherry L. West, Louise B. West, Leona 
R. West Garner (and husband Dorian Garner), his siblings William West (and wife 
Christine), Jerome West (and wife Yvonne), Carolyn Pinckney (and husband Robert), 
Charles West, Patricia Merritt (and husband Willoiam), Harold West, Jr. (and wife 
Judith), and his memory shall be forever cherished by each one of them; now therefore 
be it  
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council formally go on record extending its deepest condolences to the 

family of Leon West for their tremendous loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to the family of Leon West on behalf of the entire City Council. 

 

 

 

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of longtime Cambridge 

 
WHEREAS: 

resident Sharon Hall on August 27, 2020; and 
 
Sharon Ann Hall was born July 10, 1951 to the late Forrest Hall Sr. and Elizabeth Hall 
(née Jackson), she attended public schools in Lynn, MA and graduated from Lynn 
English High School in 1969; and  
 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS:  After graduation, Sharon Hall worked for the New England Telephone Company for 
19 years, before moving to Atlanta, GA, where she worked for many years as a Debt 
Collector at Sears Roebuck; and  
 
Sharon Hall was a stylish dresser who could put an outfit together with such class, she 
loved old school music and attended many concerts, she was an experienced ice skater, 
enjoyed reading, shopping with her sisters and friends, she was a big, big fan of the 
New England sports teams and of the Atlanta Hawks (and she particularly loved 
Lebron James), and her love of southern foods and bacon was legendary; and 
 
Sharon Hall was predeceased by her beloved son Nicholas Morris Long, Jr., and she 
leaves behind her sisters, Sandra L. Ellis of Cambridge, MA, Marcelyn D. Pearson of 
Cambridge, MA, Cheryl D. Hall of Cambridge, MA, Alla M. Hall of Cambridge, MA 
and Michele D. Saunders of Medford, MA, her brothers Forrest Hall Jr. of Cambridge 
MA, Marshall D. Hall of Lynn, MA and Brent R. Hall of Fitchburg, MA, her 
granddaughters, Makhya Long, Jordan Britt, and Makayla Long, as well as several 
nieces and nephews, and her dear friends Mary Williams and Grace Rugnetta; and 
 
Sharon Hall was a loving, caring, friendly, and feisty person who gave her heart to the 
many people that crossed her path, she loved life and she lived it to the absolute fullest, 
and her memory shall be forever cherished by all who knew her; now therefore be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council formally go on record in expressing its deepest condolences to 
the family and friends of Sharon Hall for their loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

 
WHEREAS: 

this resolution to the family of Sharon Hall on behalf of the entire City Council.

5.21

R-21 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  Latinx Heritage Month is a commemoration beginning in September through October 

15th that is intrinsically linked to the independence anniversaries of several Latin 
American nations and uplifts the cultural legacy of a group deeply rooted in rich 
traditions; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Since 1968, Latinx Heritage Month celebrates, recognizes and honors Latinx 

peoples, culture, issues, contributions and history, including their contributions 
to the economic and political advancements to our country; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Latinx Heritage Month is also referred to as Hispanic or Latino Heritage Month, but 
the term ‘Latinx’ includes members of the non-binary, gender non-conforming and 
gender expansive people, and creates space to represent the Indigenous, Brazilian, and 
other non-Spanish speaking people in the celebration; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  The Latinx population is a fast-growing community, and makes up almost 17% of the 

American population,12% of the Massachusetts population and 7.6% of the Cambridge 
population; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  The Latinx community has influenced our arts as singers, performers and writers, they 

have created and supported our small business economy as employees, owners and 
entrepreneurs, they are dedicated to the education of our youth and technological 
advancements as teachers, professors and engineers, they stand up to injustice and 
create change in our society as advocates, activists and elected officials, and they take 
care of our sick as nurses, doctors and childcare workers and risk their own well-being 
for ours by doing so; now therefore be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council recognizes September 2020 as Latinx Heritage Month and 

encourages all Cambridge residents to celebrate the achievements and contributions of 
Cambridge’s Latinx community.

R-22 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
 
WHEREAS:  Every year, millions of Americans find themselves unable to vote because they missed 
the registration deadline, didn’t update their registration, or aren’t sure how to register 
to vote; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  National Voter Registration day is a civic holiday that celebrates and encourages 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

engagement in our Democracy, with a goal to spread awareness of voting and voter 
registration so that tens of thousands of eligible voters can register to vote before the 
deadline; and 
 
Since Voter Registration day was first observed in 2012, nearly 3 million people have 
registered to vote on the day. In 2019 alone, 473,725 Americans became registered to 
vote on Voter Registration day; and 
 
In Cambridge, there are currently 71,469 registered voters, with election turnout 
fluctuating between 18-75% over the past four years in Primary and General Elections; 
and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  A large and informed electorate is essential to a working democracy on the local, state, 

and federal levels; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  National Voter Registration Day provides an opportunity to set aside differences, enjoy 

the rights and opportunities we share as Americans, and celebrate our democracy 
through the power of our vote; now therefore be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council goes on record recognizing September 22, 2020 as National 

Voter Registration day in the City of Cambridge and encourages residents to register to 
vote by October 24, 2020.

City of Cambridge 

R-23 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The Cambridge City Council is proud to congratulate local leaders who support their 

surrounding community; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  On September 1, 2020, Pakistani astrophysicist Nergis Mavalvala will become the new 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

Dean of the MIT School of Science, and the first woman and openly queer woman of 
color to ever hold the position; and 
 
Professor Mavalvala is a Curtis and Kathleen Marble Professor of Astrophysics at 
MIT. Since 2015, she has been the Associate Head of the Department of Physics. She 
is renowned for her work in gravitational-wave detection, particularly as a leading 
member of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO); and 
 
Professor Mavalvala has been recognized for a multitude of prestigious awards and 
honors, including the MacArthur “Genius” Award, the LGBTQ Scientist of the Year 
by the National Organization of Gay and Lesbian Scientists and Technical 
Professionals, and the Special Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  As the Associate Head of the Department of Physics, Professor Mavalvala also co-

 
WHEREAS: 

founded the Physics Values Committee, which is comprised of students, faculty, and 
staff with the goal to improve student-faculty relationships by advising the department 
on issues of mentorship, collaboration, and student well-being; and 
 
Professor Mavalvala was instrumental in creating a student mentoring program, 
oversaw academic programming, and worked to create a more equitable environment 
for a more diverse student body by revising graduate admissions procedures; now 
therefore be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council go on record congratulating Professor Mavalvala for her great 

work as a scholar of astrophysics, on gravitational wave detection, as a spectacular 
student and faculty mentor, and for becoming the first openly queer immigrant woman 
scientist of color to serve as the Dean of MIT’s School of Science; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and is hereby requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to Professor Nergis Mavalvala on behalf of the entire City Council.

COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

Since the COVID-19 outbreak, the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT has been a 
critical partner in COVID-19 testing in Cambridge and Massachusetts; and 
 
Since March 25, 2020, the Broad Institute has processed more than 1.1 million 
COVID-19 tests in nursing homes, homeless shelters, local neighborhoods, low-
income housing and universities in the Commonwealth; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  One in every twenty COVID-19 tests in the United States is now processed by the 

Broad Institute and they have launched the most widespread testing program 
throughout the state of Massachusetts; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  The Broad Institute will further its impact by partnering with 108 public and private 

 
WHEREAS: 

colleges and universities in Massachusetts to provide regular COVID-19 testing to 
students, faculty and staff as part of the state’s back-to-school plans; and 
 
Since the beginning of the pandemic, the Broad Institute has worked around the clock 
to provide testing to Cambridge residents and keep our Cambridge community safe; 
now therefore be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council go on record congratulating the Broad Institute for reaching this 
milestone of administering over 1 million COVID-19 tests and thanking them for their 
tireless efforts in keeping Cambridge and the surrounding communities safe; and be it 
further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and is hereby requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to the Broad Institute on behalf of the entire City Council.

It has come to the attention of the City Council that the Sufi Service Committee has 
distributed 2,608,740 articles of clothing; and    
 
Throughout the year, the Sufi Service Committee has collected and provided clothing 
to those in need, including professional clothes for individuals interviewing for work, 
high schoolers entering the job market and maternity clothes for pregnant mothers; and    
 
The Sufi Service Committee has also provided homemade meals while distributing 
clothing to our City’s most vulnerable residents; and 
 
Completely volunteer-based, the Sufi Service Committee has set and achieved 
tremendous goals in serving the community and providing necessary aid to those in 
need; now therefore be it

successful year fostering community, and wishing them continued success for many 
more years of service; and be it further

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS:  While working for Title 1, she secured funding from the Children’s Trust Fund to 

Lei-Anne Ellis began her career in the City of Cambridge 27 years ago, and has made a 
tremendous impact on our city through her steadfast commitment to our children and 
their families; and 
Lei-Anne Ellis has accomplished many noteworthy achievements and positions in her 
career with Cambridge Public Schools (CPS), Department of Human Service Programs 
(DHSP) and Public Health Department; and 
During her time with CPS, she was a Library Aide, Parent Outreach Worker, and Title 
1 Family Liaison, and she developed, created and led the Agenda for Children Literacy 
Initiative, Literacy Ambassadors and Baby University; and 
She went above and beyond as the DHSP Division Head for Childcare and Family 
Supports and the first Early Childhood Director for the Birth-3rd Grade Partnership; 
and 

conduct parenting support programs, established the monthly Title 1 calendar and Ice 
Cream Social traditions that continue today, and made sure over 80 children received 
scholarships to attend high quality preschools; and 
In every position she held, she ensured educators and family support staff were 
provided with support, coaching and professional development so that all children had 
access to high quality early education and care; and 
She went above and beyond her job duties, but most importantly, she inspired all those 
who worked with and for her to be their very best and passed along her extensive 
knowledge of early childhood to those around her; now therefore be it 
That the City Council go on record recognizing the significant professional 
achievements of Lei-Anne Ellis, expressing our gratitude for the contributions she has 
made to the City of Cambridge and its children and families over the last 27 years and 
wishing her continued good health, happiness and well-being during her retirement; 
and be it further 
That the City Clerk be and is hereby requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 
this resolution to Lei-Anne Ellis on behalf of the entire City Council.

R-31 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS:  The City Council was deeply saddened to learn of the sudden passing of Justin Waithe 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

on August 22, 2020; and 
 
Justin Aaron Leroy Waithe was born in Boston, MA, on October 8, 1979 to the Rev. 
Leroy (deceased) and Cecilia Waithe, he was brother to Sheralyn Waithe Henry and 
Joel Waithe, and as a child, Justin attended Agape Christian Academy, before later 
attending Rhema Bible Training Center and UMass Lowell; and 
 
From a very young age, it was apparent that Justin Waithe was truly gifted in the area 
of music – from his voice being the family's wake up call, recording pretend radio 
shows, singing lead parts in his school and church performances, teaching the youth in 
his church how to "step," singing the National Anthem during the playoff season for 
the Boston Celtics, singing with the Boston Pops, and being the voice a bride and 
groom would hear for their first dance, it wasn't hard to figure out that music and the 
arts would play a huge part in his life; and 
 
Justin Waithe not only showed who he was through his music, but also through his 
style and natural charisma; and 
 
Justin Waithe's deep love for his family was also evident throughout the course of his 
life, and that love was taken to the next level when his nephew and nieces were born, 
as one of his favorite titles was "Uncle," and he truly enjoyed serving in that role for 
his family and for his friends, proudly filling in the gap for the fatherless and becoming 
a surrogate uncle for some of his closest friends’ children; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Over the last several years, Justin Waithe was very passionate about people's rights, 

regardless of their race, religion, or orientation, he wanted to show people that 
disagreement and respect can coexist, he spoke with clear conviction and passion 
without ever expressing judgment or hate, because he was proud of who he was and 
wanted people to see that; and 
 
Justin Waithe’s legacy will continue to be celebrated by his Mom, siblings, nieces, 
nephew, cousins, and a host of relatives and friends, and his memory shall be forever 
cherished; now therefore be it  

 
WHEREAS: 

Packet Pg. 904

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council formally go on record in expressing its deepest condolences to 

 

the family and friends of Justin Waithe for their great loss; and be it further 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of 

this resolution to the family of Justin Waithe on behalf of the entire City Council. 

5.31

 

 

 

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;  
 
 
 
ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

6.1

City of Cambridge 

O-1 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

      

COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
 
WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

WHEREAS: 

ORDERED: 

On the night of October 16, 2010, Danroy “DJ” Henry went out in 
Pleasantville, NY with teammates, celebrating the win of Pace University’s 
Homecoming Football Game; and 
 
DJ’s parents, Angela Henry and Danroy Henry Sr. both attended Cambridge 
Rindge and Latin High School, connecting them to our city and this council; 
and 
 
Unrelated to the Pace University group, a fight broke out and local police 
were called; and   
DJ was asked by police to move his car out of a fire lane where he was 
waiting for his teammates, and as he moved his car, he was fired upon by 
Officer Aaron Hess of the Pleasantville PD; and 
DJ was shot 3 times as he drove, pulled from the car, handcuffed, then left 
face down on the street unattended, dying, with 3 bullet wounds to his chest; 
and  
Initial reports, which suggested that DJ was shot because he tried to run over 
officer Hess, were later deemed to be untrue. In fact, DJ was moving his car 
in compliance with the officers’ request; and 
Ronald Beckley, a 30-year veteran officer of Westchester County, admitted 
that in his opinion, officer Hess was the aggressor and not DJ. He further 
stated that he shot officer Hess in the leg because he did not know who he 
was and thought that he was the aggressor, and that he was not sure why Hess 
“had placed himself in front of the car”; and 
No charges have been filed against officer Hess despite this new evidence; 
and   
Since the death of DJ, it has become more and more evident that Black and 
Brown people have been killed by the hands of white police officers, 
something that has been going on long before DJ’s death, but has gained 
increased visibility due to cell phone video and police body cameras; and 
The Henry family deserve a new investigation into the killing of their son; 
now therefore be it 
That the Cambridge City Council go on record requesting that the Danroy 
“DJ” Henry’s case be reopened; that officer Aaron Hess be charged for 
excessive use of force, negligent treatment of life in the death of DJ Henry; 
and that a formal apology and acknowledgement of the misinformation that 
was knowingly stated by the Westchester Police Department and others be 
made to the Henry family; and be it further 

Packet Pg. 906

ORDERED: 

That an official copy of this resolution be sent to the Westchester Police 
Chief, the Westchester District Attorney, the Governor of New York, and 
New York Senators Chuck Schumer and Kristen Gillibrand.

Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
ORDERED: 

Over the course of the past year, a number of residents of the LBJ Apartments, located 
at 150 Erie Street, have voiced concerns that vehicles are frequently illegally parking 
in front of their building; and  
 
The space in front of this building, which is home to mostly senior citizens, is reserved 
for emergency vehicles such as ambulances and fire trucks, and LBJ residents have 
cited fears that the vehicles they regularly see illegally parked in front of their building 
could impede the work of first responders, which could have potentially deadly 
consequences in an emergency; and 
 
This issue has been brought to the attention of the City and the Cambridge Police over 
the course of the past year, but unfortunately no lasting solutions have been found, 
leaving LBJ residents frustrated over what they view as a potential hazard to their 
safety; now therefore be it  
 
That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to ask the Director of Traffic, 
Parking, and Transportation, the Cambridge Police Department, and any other relevant 
City personnel to collaborate with the Cambridge Housing Authority in formulating 
plans that will lead to increased enforcement of the parking regulations in front of 150 
Erie Street, that will discourage illegal parking in front of the building, and to report 
back to the City Council on this matter in a timely manner.  

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;

6.3

O-3 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS:  

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
ORDERED: 

It has come to the City Council’s attention that there is a recurring problem on 
Columbia Street involving the placement of trash and discarded furniture on the streets 
during the final weekend of each of the summer months, coinciding with the periods of 
greatest annual tenant turnover; and  
 
There are several multi-family homes on Columbia Street that are mostly owned by 
out-of-town landlords, and unfortunately there are no incentives for these landlords to 
ensure that their outgoing tenants be mindful of the City’s trash pick-up schedule when 
they leave, leading to the excessive placement of discarded items on the streets when 
the tenants move out, and a sense of blight and neglect in the area; and  
 
The discarded furniture and trash piles are often left out for several days between 
scheduled trash pick-ups, forcing residents of Columbia Street to regularly contact the 
City to request that the DPW be dispatched to pick up the discarded trash – a task 
which the DPW unfailingly does, and which the Columbia Street residents are grateful 
for; and  
 
As this is an issue that seems to recur each year during the summer months, the City 
should be able to anticipate the need for increased DPW trash pick-ups on Columbia 
Streets during the months of June – September each year and be able to build this into 
the DPW’s schedule of service, so that it does not continue to fall upon the Columbia 
Street residents to request this additional service each summer; now therefore be it  
 
That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to ask the Director of the Public 
Works Department to review this matter, establish a plan that is responsive to the 
concerns of the Columbia Street residents, and report back to the City Council on this 
matter in a timely manner.  

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;  
 
 
 
ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

6.4

FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR CARLONE 
 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

The COVID-19 pandemic has fundamentally changed the way that public spaces are 
designed and the need for open, outdoor space has dramatically increased; and 

 
Local businesses are struggling to stay afloat, and it is not clear when restaurants and 
retail will be safely able to have close to their full capacity of patrons inside; during 
this unknown period, outdoor retail and dining remains an important lifeline; and 

 
There have been numerous attempts to improve pedestrian and cyclist safety and slow 
traffic in Harvard Square after multiple fatalities have occurred over the past three 
years; and 

 
Recent studies have shown the myriad benefits that come from the pedestrianization of 
city centers, including an increase in commercial activity, and improved street life and 
safety; and 

 
Cities, including those with a similar climate to Cambridge, such as Burlington, 
Vermont and Boulder, Colorado, have permanently closed several blocks of central 
city streets creating open spaces for retail, restaurant and resident strolling; and cities 
in Europe of all sizes have had success with pedestrianized areas of urban centers; and  

 
The Council unanimously passed an order asking for certain streets in Harvard Square 
be closed to vehicle traffic on a select number of days during the summer of 2020; now 
the idea of having a permanent plan for open space and outdoor dining is appropriate; 
and 

 
The Envision Cambridge Masterplan states, “By encouraging vibrancy on streets in the 
city’s retail districts, Cambridge can ensure these commercial areas continue to meet 
the everyday needs of the city’s population. Vibrancy can be fostered both through 
street design and retail district programming”; and 

WHEREAS:  Moody Street in Waltham has been a vibrant destination over the summer as the entire 

street has been closed to vehicle traffic to make space for outdoor dining and retail; 
now therefore be it 

 

 

Packet Pg. 910

6.4

ORDERED: 

 
ORDERED: 

 
ORDERED: 

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to confer with the Traffic, Parking 
and Transportation Department, the Community Development Department, the 
Harvard Square Business Association, the Harvard Square Neighborhood Association 
and Harvard University on the implementing a pilot program to close some streets on 
weekends and possibly weeknights in Harvard Square.  Prior to closing, the Traffic, 
Parking and Transportation Department should conduct extensive outreach to impacted 
businesses to ensure that the closures would not prevent deliveries and other essential 
operations of those businesses; and be it further 

 
That the City Manager is requested to establish a stakeholder committee to study traffic 
impacts of any further to determine if street modifications would work towards 
fulfilling city goals; the committee would include representation from Traffic, Parking 
and Transportation Department, the Community Development Department, the 
Harvard Square Business Association, the Harvard Square Neighborhood Association, 
and Harvard University, the City Pedestrian and Bicycles Committee, Mid-Cambridge 
Neighborhood Association and Cambridge Bicycle Safety and further be it  
 
That the City Manager report back to the City Council before October 1. 

 

 

 

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Charter Right by a yea and nay vote:- 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

City of Cambridge 

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
 
WHEREAS:  National Recovery Month is a national observance to commemorate individuals on a 

journey to recovery and to raise awareness on how substance use treatment and mental 
health services can enable those with mental and substance use disorders to live 
healthy and rewarding lives; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Doctors, experts, and loved ones come together to stress the importance of continuing 

treatment as part of the recovery process and to prevent further addictions; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Each September, Recovery Month works to promote and support new evidence-based 

 
WHEREAS: 

treatment and recovery practices, the emergence of a strong and proud recovery 
community, and the dedication of service providers and community members across 
the nation who make recovery in all its forms possible; and 
 
It is important to recognize the signs within our own loved ones, show support and 
compassion, and give them the support they need during their recovery process; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the stressors that might lead to substance 

use, and we must come together and help those in need; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  Throughout Recovery Month, we emphasize the message that treatment is available, 

and the process of recovery can be effective; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  The City of Cambridge, Cambridge Public Health Department, mental health supports, 

and advocacy organizations are dedicated to reach all residents and underscore the 
universal importance of mental health and recovery programs for those struggling from 
addiction; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  The City of Cambridge continues to raise awareness about mental health and physical 
health while also providing solutions that sustain long-term recoveries; now therefore 
be it 
 

 
RESOLVED:  That the City Council go on record recognizing September 2020 as Recovery 
Awareness Month in the City of Cambridge; and be it further 
 
That the City Manager is hereby requested to direct the appropriate City staff to light 
up City Hall purple for no less than one week in recognition of Recovery Awareness 
Month. 

 
ORDERED: 

Packet Pg. 913

Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

O-6 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

As national COVID-19 cases reach 6.2 million, vaccine developers have begun 
hundreds of clinical trials; and 
 
Currently, there are 45 vaccine trials in Phases I-III of the vaccine approval process, 
with 8 already in Phase III; and 
 

 
WHEREAS:  When a vaccine is approved and becomes available, the City of Cambridge and our 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
ORDERED: 

Public Health Department must have a plan on how the vaccine will be equitably 
disseminated; and 
 
A plan will ensure residents feel confident in our public health officials’  
allocation and distribution of any vaccine that becomes available; and   
 
The plan must maintain equity at the forefront of vaccine dissemination and 
information sharing, including that we: 
•  Ensure essential workers, communities of color and low-income residents receive 
critical information to aid their decision-making around COVID-19 vaccination; 
•  Partner with community groups, health care provider networks, universities, state 
and local peers, federal authorities, and other stakeholders, in conducting rapid 
response research and message development and testing; 

•  Provide residents with clear and timely explanations regarding COVID-19 vaccine 

allocation and distribution strategies; 

•  Develop operational systems including nontraditional locations to provide 

vaccines, such as faith centers, grocery stores, schools, senior centers, offices, etc.; 
•  Work to establish a public oversight committee to review and report on COVID-19 
vaccination systems, ensuring allocation is fair, target groups receive vaccine, and 
populations disproportionately affected by the pandemic are justly served; and 

•  Mandate inclusive committee membership that reflects the jurisdiction’s 

demographic make-up, incorporates diverse sectors including business and faith 
communities, and involves experts in public health, vaccination, and ethics; now 
therefore be it 

 
 
 
The City Manager be and hereby is requested to work with Claude Jacob, Chief Public 
Health Officer of the Cambridge Public Health Department to appoint a Vaccine Task 
Force to develop a plan that keeps equity at the forefront with the above 
recommendations; and be it further 
 

Packet Pg. 915

ORDERED: 

That a diversity of community members and stakeholders be equally represented on 
this Task Force, that the Task Force should work to solicit the opinions and expertise 
of other affected stakeholders, and that this Task Force should hold its first meeting 
within two months of the adoption of this Policy Order, and report back to the City 
Council by December 21, 2020.

FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

 
 
 

 

 

 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS:

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN 
COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN 
 
WHEREAS: 

The U.S. census provides critical data to determine how federal funding is allocated to 
a city’s hospitals, fire departments, schools, roads, and other resources; and 
 
The results of the census also determine the number of seats each state will have in the 
U.S. House of Representatives, and they are used to draw congressional and state 
legislative districts; and 
 
The stakes are even higher during a global pandemic, and we must work together to 
complete the most accurate count of Cambridge residents to ensure proper funding 
distribution, fair government representation, and appropriate, data-informed school and 
voting district designations for the next 10 years; and 
 
To date, the City of Cambridge has employed many strategies to reach Cambridge 
residents and increase census turnout, including nightly Citywide emails, the formation 
of a multi-sector Cambridge Complete Count Committee, outreach events at Fresh 
Pond apartments, creating and disseminating materials in eight languages (public 
buildings, businesses, community spaces), through the school's Backpack Express 
program, on social media, at Bluebikes stations, through videos with CCTV and 22-
CityView, online and more; and 
 
There have been expected obstacles due to the COVID-19 pandemic, such as 
decreased engagement, concerns about security in providing personal information, and 
gaps in computer and/or internet access that deny opportunities to respond online; and 
 
As of September 2, 2020, 65% of Cambridge residents have responded to the  
2020 Census, down from the 2010 census response rate of 73%; and 
 

deadline extended to September 30, 2020, which gives us two more weeks to collect as 
much information as possible; and 
 
The Cambridge Public Schools Food and Nutrition team will begin supplying free 
breakfast and lunch again Monday through Friday starting September 14, 2020; and 
 
Food distribution sites at schools and affordable housing locations are a resource for 
many community members, and gives us an opportunity to meet the community where 
they already are; now therefore be it 
 

 
WHEREAS:  We have a unique opportunity to continue our outreach efforts with the census’ 

Packet Pg. 917

ORDERED: 

That the City Manager confer with the CPS Food and Nutrition team and Cambridge 
Complete Count Committee on deploying Census outreach at food distribution sites for 
the remainder of September.

Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 

Packet Pg. 918

 
 
 

 

 

 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
ORDERED: 

 
ORDERED: 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS 
 
WHEREAS: 

6.8

O-8 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

The Mayor’s Disaster Relief Fund Grant and Loan program has been established to 
serve as a financial lifeline to our local small business community during the covid-19 
crisis, providing grants to businesses of up to $10,000, which will not have to be 
repaid, and zero interest loans of up to $15,000 from the Cambridge Redevelopment 
Authority; and 
 
The Mayor’s Disaster Relief Fund Grant and Loan program was initially promoted as 
prioritizing “…businesses that have been more severely affected by the impact of the 
COVID-19 Pandemic,” and that its funds could be used toward paying such expenses 
as “…the average rent, salaries, utilities and cost of goods” that other programs do not 
cover; and 
 
At the City Council meeting held on July 27, 2020, the possibility of expanding the 
scope of organizations that would be eligible to receive funds from this program was 
raised, even as members of the City Council were hearing from some local small 
business owners that they had not previously heard about this program, or that they felt 
they had been unfairly left out of consideration for obtaining these critical funds; and 
 
The City must ensure that it has conducted truly aggressive outreach to the 
community’s most vulnerable businesses – particularly the Black and Minority-owned 
businesses, to those who are not members of the neighborhood business associations, 
and to those who may not rely heavily upon electronic communication – to ensure that 
these entities have been given every reasonable opportunity to participate in the 
Mayor’s Disaster Relief Fund Grant and Loan program; now therefore be it 
 
That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to report back to the City Council on 
what specific outreach methods have been conducted to the City’s small businesses, 
particularly those Black and Minority-owned small businesses, to ensure that these 
entities have been given every reasonable opportunity to participate in and receive 
funding from the Mayor’s Disaster Relief Fund Grant and Loan program; and be it 
further 
 
That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to direct the Community 
Development Department and any other appropriate City personnel to establish a 
means of providing technical support to marginalized, underrepresented business 
owners in applying for and obtaining the critical funds from the Mayor’s Disaster 
Relief Fund Grant and Loan program, and/or from other similar State and Federal 
assistance programs, and to report back to the City Council on this matter in a timely 
manner.   

Packet Pg. 919

Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

6.9

O-9 
FIRST IN COUNCIL 
September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

MAYOR SIDDIQUI 
VICE MAYOR MALLON 
COUNCILLOR NOLAN 
COUNCILLOR TOOMEY 
 
WHEREAS: 

“Wastewater,” also referred to as “sewage,” includes water from household/  
building use (i.e., toilets, showers, sinks) that can contain human fecal waste, as  
well as water from non-household sources (i.e., rainwater and industrial use);  
and  
 

 
WHEREAS:  Wastewater can be tested for RNA from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes  

 
WHEREAS: 

COVID-19; and 
 
SARS-CoV-2 can be shed in the feces of individuals with COVID-19, thus it  
can provide an early warning sign of a potential outbreak since many  
asymptomatic individuals are not getting tested; and  
 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS:  Wastewater testing has been used for years as an effective method for detecting  
any virus that can be transmitted asymptomatically and was instrumental in the  
Global Polio Eradication Initiative; and 
 
Currently, researchers around the world – in the United States, Canada, New  
Zealand, Singapore, China, Spain, United Kingdom, Netherlands and more –  
are testing wastewater to study and understand the prevalence of COVID-19  
infection rates to help prevent COVID-19 outbreaks; and 
 
The University of Arizona reported signs of a COVID-19 outbreak before it  
Started by testing their wastewater; and 
 
Cambridge Public School District is relying on several metrics to determine  
back to school planning, including the rate of positive test rate below 5%, less  
than 25 new cases per day/per 100,00, and sewage monitoring showing less  
than 100 copies of RNA per mL; and 
 
Collecting additional data provides more information for our public health  
departments to make informed, data-driven decisions for reopening and can  
reveal COVID-19 hotspots up to one to two weeks earlier than current  
individual testing; now therefore be it 
 
That the City Manager confer with the Department of Public Works, the  
Cambridge Water Department and other relevant partners to create a pilot  
program for wastewater testing for evidence of COVID-19. 

 
ORDERED: 

 
ORDERED: 

Packet Pg. 921

 

 

6.9

In City Council September 14, 2020. 
Order Adopted by a yea and nay vote:- 
Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1. 
Attest:- Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk 
 
A true copy;  
 
 
 
ATTEST:-                              

Anthony I. Wilson, City Clerk

September 14, 2020 

 

 

 
 
 

 

 

 

 

      

City of Cambridge 

COUNCILLOR SOBRINHO-WHEELER 
 
WHEREAS: 

The COVID-19 pandemic has changed housing situations and travel patterns for 
Cantabrigians, with many residents temporarily sheltering family members and other 
loved ones; and 
 
Cambridge’s permit parking requirements require visitors with cars to display a Visitor 
Parking Permit and park in a designated zone; and 
 
Current construction in Visitor Permit Area 14, which even normally has minimal 
street parking, has significantly reduced available space in that Permit Area even 
further; and 
 
The Traffic, Parking, and Transportation Department has shown flexibility in other 
aspects of parking requirements during the pandemic by not enforcing meters and other 
restrictions for significant periods of time; now therefore be it 
 
That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to work with the Traffic, Parking, 
and Transportation Department to examine solutions for residents with visitors in 
Permit Area 14 such as allowing parking in another Zone or access to nearby City 
garages; and be it further 
 
That the City Manager shall report back to the Council on this in a timely manner. 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
WHEREAS: 

 
ORDERED: 

 
ORDERED:

Yeas 8; Nays 0; Absent 1.
